I found John wick 4 to be a bit of a mixed experience. On the positive side, the film excels in its cinematography and choreography. The visuals are striking, with each frame meticulously crafted to enhance the action scenes. The fight sequences are as thrilling as ever, showcasing some impressive stunt work and choreography that keeps the action engaging. The lead performance continues to be a highlight, bringing a compelling intensity that anchors the film.

However, the film stumbles in several areas. The plot is filled with implausibilities that can be distracting, making it hard to fully suspend disbelief. The story, while action-packed, doesn't feel as fresh or captivating as previous entries in the series. The villain, unfortunately, lacks the depth and menace that would make for a more memorable adversary. This installment also suffers from pacing issues, with some moments dragging on longer than necessary.

This, the fourth, and final, chapter of the main John Wick story, sees the High Table sending Marquis Vincent Bisset de Gramont to eliminate John Wick. Along with an array of expendable fighters he takes Caine, a blind assassin and friend of Wick's. Obviously Wick isn't going to take this lying down and in a struggle that takes the action to Paris via Berlin and Osaka, finds a way that might just end his problems. Of course he still has one or two friends who will help him when needed.

If you are after a deep and meaningful story the John Wick franchise probably isn't for you. If however you want almost non-stop fight scenes and action then this delivers and then some. As the story moves from city to city we get a variety of different action. All of it is very intense. We get plenty of gunplay as well as fights involving knives, axes and hand to hand combat. While the fighting feels gruelling and our protagonist gets genuinely hurt at times other aspects are fairly stylised... such as people in a Berlin club continuing to dance as mayhem erupts around them and a fight amongst the traffic circling the Arc de Triomphe. The cast is solid; most obviously Keanu Reeves who dominates the film as John Wick. Donnie Yen impresses as Caine, the blind assassin presumably inspired by Zatoichi the blind swordsman; Shamier Anderson is fun as Mr. Nobody, a tracker with a dog. It was also good to see Ian McShane and Lance Reddick return as Winston and Cheron, the manager and concierge of the New York Continental. Overall I'd say that although I understand some people didn't enjoy it this is still a must see for action fans.

John Wick 4 is great with lots of weapons and glass breaking. The flow and pacing was great on the edge of my seat the first time I watched it.

A portion through the movie it's unavoidable to notice the exact same colour of yellow or orange being used. Every where that John wick went the same lights are every where. Is there some kind of mafia that's forcing everyone to adopt their lights in order to be the sole provider of LED lighting.

Seeing the same colours in too many scenes took my attention away from the movie.

Movies like the matrix that has that greenish wash to it pulled it off naturally. Same as Bladerunner.

Personally I would not know how to do it better other than seeing it and saying that's what would work better, so it's still thumbs up from me for the comic book style of lighting.

The lighting mafia could have made a cool side story where it's a battle of light and dark.

Those who cling to death; live.

Those who cling to life; die.

The John Wick series' third instalment already exceeded and stood tall above the standards of Hollywood action features, but this fourth installment has now gone above and beyond all conceivable boundaries and limitations, redeeming both itself and the series as a whole as one of, if not the best, action blockbusters available.

The movie set unimaginably high standards; it established a benchmark for others to follow and imitate, but I doubt anyone in the distant future will be able to. The fourth chapter of John Wick is stuffed with action and Reeves' uncompromising swagger, and the most surprising aspect is that they never seem to become redundant.

The director, Chad Stahelski, deserves credit for ensuring that the stunts did not become dull or monotonous. The fight scenes are skillfully choreographed, and the camera work captures every move seamlessly. The audience is on the edge of their seats, awaiting the outcome of what occurs next. And believe me, it's easier said than done.

In addition to the nail-biting action and breathtaking style, we have a slew of intriguing new characters (Caine, Marquis, and Tracker, to name a few) who inject much-needed freshness and thrill into the plot! Donnie Yen shone the brightest among them all. As much as I admire Bill Skarsgard and Hiroyuki Sanada, it must be stated unequivocally that Donnie Yen was the indisputable standout, second only to Keanu Reeves, the lead.

Undoubtedly, there's no John Wick movie that I like more than the first one. Here, Keanu Reeves appears much less energetic, I would even say he looks tired. While watching it with a close friend, he said, "Of course he's tired, if you watch the movies in order, he's been hit again and again, he even fell off a building in the previous film." I agree with that, but if we judge this movie solely on its own, (unlike the other installments), In this, it seems like the characters "let themselves be killed" by John. This is perfectly reflected in the supposed enemy who is on par with the great John Wick, the man who can kill everyone in a bar armed only with a pencil. The biggest enemy to defeat in this movie is..."a blind man." As I mentioned in the title, I appreciate that they didn't extend the franchise more than necessary. The beautiful soundtrack and the care they have for the created lore are appreciated. Of course, this leads to some script conveniences, but since the first John Wick movie, he was killing everyone, and neither the police nor the FBI put him on the most wanted list, so as a viewer, you can forgive those details because they are "part of that world," that world created with so much love.

In short: a good movie.

Wick needs to go from spot A to spot B. There are hundreds of enemies trying to kill him. He will fight against them all alone and will kill them with his weapon. Now he is at the spot B and needs to go to spot C. There are hundreds of enemies trying to kill him. He will fight against them all alone and will kill them with his weapon. Now he is at the spot C and needs to go to spot D. There are hundreds of enemies trying to kill him. He will fight against them all alone and will kill them with his weapon. Now he is at the spot D and needs to go to spot E. Yeah that's the same over and over again for three hours. Make yourself a favor a skip this movie. Thank me later.

Watched John Wick Chapter 4 an amazing Performances by Keanu Reeves(Cyberpunk 2077,The Matrix Resurrections) as John Wick and Donnie Yen(Ip Man Series, Rogue One) as Caine, making her debut Rina Sawayama as Akira, The Late Lance Reddick(Horizon: Forbidden West) as Charon, Ian McShane(Deadwood) as Winston Scott, Laurence Fishburne(The Matrix) as The Bowery King,Shamie Anderson(Awake) as Tracker/Mr. Nobody, Hiroyuki Sanada(The Wolverine,Bullet Train) as Koji , Scott Adkins(Doctor Strange) as Killa, Clancy Brown(Starship Troopers) as The Harbinger and Bill Skarsgard(Eternals) as The Marquis Vincent de Gramont .

I thought John Wick Chapter 4 was awesome glad Star Wars Alum Donnie Yen Joined this Looking forward to Ballerina & Ghost of Tsushima as the same creators also films ending is open ended Keanu Reeves is gonna take a break as with creators.

Score By Tyler Bates(John Wick Chapter 3), Cinematography By Dan Lausten(The Shape Of Water) and Direction By Chad Stahelski(John Wick) , A Epic "Conclusion" to The John Wick Saga 8/10.

John Wick Chapter 4 takes the exhilarating adrenaline rush of its predecessors and amplifies it to a new level, delivering an awe-inspiring cinematic experience that leaves audiences on the edge of their seats. This action-packed masterpiece, directed by Chad Stahelski, proves that the franchise still has plenty of steam and creativity to offer, while honoring its roots and the beloved character that has become a cultural icon.

Keanu Reeves once again embodies the enigmatic and charismatic titular character, John Wick, with an unparalleled level of dedication. Reeves effortlessly blends stoic determination and genuine emotional depth, making John Wick a character audiences can't help but root for. It's rare to witness an action star who can evoke such raw emotion, and Reeves pulls it off flawlessly.

The action sequences in John Wick Chapter 4 are nothing short of breathtaking. Choreographed to perfection, every fight, every gun battle, and every chase scene is a visual spectacle that sets a new standard for action filmmaking. The balletic precision with which Wick dispatches his enemies is mesmerizing, and it's evident that the filmmakers have raised the bar for action choreography in the industry.

But beyond the adrenaline-pumping action, the film also delves deeper into the emotional core of John Wick. This chapter explores his internal conflict and the price he continues to pay for the life he once led. As we learn more about his past, the film cleverly weaves together intricate layers of storytelling that keep us engaged and emotionally invested in his journey.

Adding to the film's allure is a stellar supporting cast. Halle Berry shines as Sofia, a fellow assassin and old friend of John Wick, bringing her own impressive skills to the relentless action sequences. Berry's portrayal of a fiercely loyal and independent character adds a refreshing dynamic to the movie.

The film's stunning cinematography deserves special mention as well. The beautifully crafted visuals complement the dark and mysterious world of assassins, presenting a visually striking backdrop that perfectly captures the essence of the John Wick universe.

Furthermore, the film's musical score, composed by Tyler Bates and Joel J. Richard, elevates the entire experience to another level. The combination of heart-pounding tracks and subtle, emotionally resonant melodies enhances every scene, further immersing the audience in this intense and thrilling world.

John Wick Chapter 4 is a masterclass in action filmmaking and storytelling. It's a rare gem that successfully continues a beloved franchise while expanding its horizons and leaving room for even more excitement in the future. Chad Stahelski and his team have crafted a seamless blend of pulse-pounding action, genuine emotion, and compelling characters, setting a new standard for action cinema.

In conclusion, John Wick Chapter 4 is an absolute triumph, delivering on every level and giving fans exactly what they've been craving. Keanu Reeves' performance, the jaw-dropping action, the emotional depth, and the overall craftsmanship make this installment a must-see for anyone who appreciates cinematic excellence. Prepare to be amazed, thrilled, and moved - John Wick is back, and he's better than ever.

I enjoyed this movie very much. From the scenery to the music, this film is great. The scenery, the sets and the cinematography are one of the best i have ever seen. There are some top down scenes that intensifies the action and the gunfight. The music is always appropriate to what you are watching and it's great. It really shows they know what they are doing when they accompany some great scenes with even greater songs. The plot is a continuation from the previous, where we see John Wick attempting to take revenge for the life they ruined. Overall, i think is a great movie and I highly recommend watching it.

Really a great thriller movie. It has surprised to its viewers with something new. When you go to the cinema hall you will see a new content , scene and will applaud . Don't miss the scene when there will be a first part club music. Really 10 star rating. Joh wick have a great action thriller and the most important is you can see the camera angles the way it's directed the scene were really amazing. You will think what will be next and will be surprised when the people of the high table starts attacking John Wick. Also it has shown in the start about the women empowerment and the message that friendship is everything always maintain. And the women are more stronger than what we think.

I'm very confused by the ratings for this movie. It was super fun and had some really cool world building but John Wick getting hit by 100 cars and bouncing up, using his jacket like it's Vibranium, and effortless shooting through the full armor of villains was fun but absurd. The gun trick at the end was really obvious, like how would that person not realize John didn't fire? The sound editing and the angle of the camera make it very easy to see all this. I do not get why this is getting rated higher than other Wick movies. One was small budget and really clever and tight, and 2 was bigger and more action but still realistic. 3 gets a little more absurd but by the stair scene in the 4th movie it's like a DC movie because it's too dark for marvel.

Amazing movie overall. Gets too slow in the beginning, but as story proceeds, John Wick gets into the action. Best cinematography and action sequences. Also, locations and ambience in the movie were really good. The tone of the movie was serious business. Unlike other John Wick chapters this one contains some funny parts, which is a plus. Background music is just same as the others, and really suits to the style and action. Best chapter in all JW series and it is a must watch.

Also, this JW chapter does travel across multiple nations and involves different characters from different ethinics :)

Watched the movie and i truly enjoyed it. John Wick chapter 4 is a perfect sequel and on the whole a perfect action movie. Firstly i should mention the incredible fight scenes where choreography,camera movement and placement ,colours, landscapes and music contribute to make them unique and intersting. Of course that is the reason the first three movies had succes and thus this one succesfully succeeds them. The style and tone that is created via lighting,scenery,colour,music and acting is unique and aesthetically beautifull. The action varies,being rarely repetitive and it is easy to follow the plot ,(wich is an excuse so the action scenes could happen).

On the other hand the movie ,(as expected from a john wick sequel ),is filled with violence and deaths as john wick proceeds to murder half the population of Paris and every assassin that comes after him. As i said it is a John Wick movie.

On the whole for its genre JohnWick chapter 4 is a masterpiece.

Just when you think a sequel of an action movie couldn't possibly get any better. It did. John Wick 4 is just phenomenal from beginning to end. And I'm even saying this as someone who doesn't exactly envy action movies in general.

John Wick 4 has such a spectacular cast and the action is always top notch. The choreography is so good it makes other action movies seem mediocre. To put it in perspective, Keanu Reeves did an amazing job with his gun-fu and hand to hand combat. Donnie Yen also did splendid being that blind assassin like he's Daredevil but with a sword.

All the characters are interesting and they aren't too much of a cliche villain or are they any bit bland. Even though I thought the main villain, the Marquis, kinda felt like he wasn't at all a serious villain to fear but to poke fun at, it wasn't comically goofy. Of course the other characters like Caine and Mr. Nobody are perfect deuteragonist that try to hunt down John but end up teaming up sorta.

Obviously the story, the bad guys, the seemingly infinite ammo are all complaints I do have with the movie. If you were looking for a serious story drama then this movie ain't it. I mean there were some points in the movie where logic and reason doesn't make any sense, not to mention John's insane pain tolerance he has in all the fight scenes. He can get hit by two cars and still get back up like he's some video game character. Or perhaps the suits the assassins wear; bullet proof suits that can "deflect" bullets instead of absorb them.

Plus, there were some action scenes that felt like a repeat of each other, like the usual flip and shoot the guy in the head move that John likes to pull off. But there were a lot of new action scenes that were amazing to watch, like John fighting Caine for the first time. Or John with nunchucks.

Overall, I think this is a great finale for John Wick that delivers great action, breathtaking cinematography, and a star studded cast that delivers. Of course if you're looking for a serious story, then don't expect anything but utter chaos. You have to watch this movie with low expectations and a mindset for orchestrated action.

John Wick is back doing what he does best that is bashing up the bad guys and many of them one after another without apparent serious injury or fatigue to self. It's all about honour, confrontation, vendetta, distress and pain. The movie has a runtime of 169 minutes which is high by normal standards. It all looks entertaining though and audiences will get their money's worth in this chapter 4 of this franchise. The stunts are all there with long duration scenes of gunfire, fist fights, shattering glass etc etc and no one stops to reload. For those who appreciate cinematography there are some fascinating shots of the action and for stunt lovers there are some new moves in addition to the conventional ones. John or his body double tumbling down four flights of stairs is done and photographed well. Another top shot capturing the action in adjoining rooms is done artistically. The script also some sharp dialogue like " One's ambition should not exceed his self worth" and " A man has to look his best when he is going to be married or buried ".

Director Chad Stahelski has packed the movie with extended scenes of action with a few emotional scenes too. He has made an effective use of a few unorthodox camera angles to enhance the impact of action. The narrative focuses on John's attempt to get back his honour by getting his declared excommunication annulled from the high table. He has to deal with a few sinister and dangerous characters at various stages. The climax is a longish exercise with mayhem taking place on the streets of Paris near the Effiel Tower as John fights off gangs of ruffians in the midst of moving traffic. The choreography of the action is mind boggling. The situation is also bizarre since the local radio station gives a brief live commentary to the accompaniment of rock music. All this happens while John is on his way to take part in an arranged duel. A short scene after the end credit titles should not be missed.

I really liked the first 3. And really hated this one. I thought the action sequences were stupid like one that reminded me of the scene in Hot Rod where Andy Samberg goes flying down and a hill and doesn't stop for miles. Apparently this is one of John Wick's new superpowers, to be able to survive long falls. The Scout character is extra stupid and unnecessary. I don't understand his motivation. There's too many characters here that are supposed to be important. I just found everything confusing and redundant. There may have been one or two scenes that I liked but I can't even think which they are. Keannu is too slow now to pull these fight scenes off. Donnie reprises his role from Star Wars Rogue One. I just think it's a messy movie.

As a Hollywood action movie junkie, I was thrilled to catch the latest installment in the John Wick franchise, Chapter 4. And let me tell you, it did not disappoint.

Keanu Reeves once again delivers a jaw-dropping performance as the titular character, John Wick. The film picks up right where Chapter 3 left off, with John on the run from the High Table after breaking the rules of the assassin's world.

The action sequences in Chapter 4 are simply incredible. From hand-to-hand combat to gun fights, the choreography is top-notch and will leave you on the edge of your seat. And the fact that Reeves does most of his own stunts only adds to the realism and intensity of the fight scenes.

But it's not just the action that makes this movie great. The story is also compelling, with John seeking revenge against those who have wronged him while also trying to navigate the complex world of assassins and their rules.

The supporting cast also shines in Chapter 4, with standout performances from Ian McShane, Laurence Fishburne, and newcomer Donnie Yen. And of course, the dogs make a welcome return and are just as badass as ever.

Overall, John Wick: Chapter 4 is a must-see for fans of the franchise and action movie lovers in general. It's a thrilling ride from start to finish and leaves you eagerly anticipating the next installment.

Cinematic no less! Story meh . This is the conclusion to John wick series . At this point I feel there's nothing left they could've filmed . We see what happens to John at the end and Keanu's says there will be no more films . I have to say the first of the installments was great . Seemed to go downward from there . Nothing we haven't seen in John wick . First film . I loved the camera work and shots and unique settings but after a while just waiting for this film to end . We get closure with Keanu and his wife who the story begins with . Love the max headroom blind Chinese man fighter ! The dogs were okay hahah . All in all typical John wick film . "Ya" and that's it . We see John buried next to his wife at the end.

It kept me on the edge of my seat for the entire time. Is the story interesting, a bit... Is the action there? Yes. It's not a thriller, it's an action movie. The choreography is fantastic and the production design is second to none. I have a background in lighting design (for theater) and the design is A-MA-ZING. Is it an exaggeration of everything (lighting/set/fighting)? Yes it is. I, for one, really enjoyed the look, style and scenography A LOT. You shouldn't view this as a story, but as an experience and a prime example of production design. Keanu Reeves and all his co-stars (and production/design team) should be proud of what they achieved: a fantastic addition to the action genre.

I haven't read all the reviews, so pardon my ignorance if my comment is repetitive. I was highly amused by the director's "borrowing" of scenes from the movie "The Warriors" during John Wick's travails during his journey to reach the site of the final duel. Especially obvious were the scenes where lady radio announcer provided the play-by-play location of John while exhorting the mob chasing him to pick up the pace. It was such a flashback for me that I thought for a moment that it was the same announcer from "The Warriors", except she would be much older now. Maybe this and the whole final chase sequence were easter eggs provided by the director and producers as a nod to the original action-packed sequence leading to the ultimate conclusion. Then again maybe "The Warriors" borrowed it to pay homage to an earlier movie.

Otherwise, a great action movie for the ages. I was exhausted at the end, nothing was left on the table. If in fact John Wick is dead, it was a satisfying ending.

If you liked the others, you'll like this one two. The film dives further into the world its depicting. We get to see new friends and new enemies. And more of the high/low table and other continental establishments throughout the world. I really enjoyed Donnie Yen's performance as a blind man, he did a great job! Honestly my favorite character in the film. Not surprised to see Bill Skarsgard in this one, he's been making a name for himself lately and this role was definitely one for him. The action scenes as always were stunning along with the visuals, scripts and just about everything. I did find the movie a little long and some of it felt too over the top for me. The main thing that always drew me to John Wick is that he felt like a real man, who could take on the world. But part four takes that away with some extremely unrealistic things. Wasn't super pleased with the direction of the ending. But all in all pretty good movie.

This latest instalment of historic franchise John Wick sees the longest runtime of the series to date. Possibly as each latest film, the films runtime went on further.

There seems to be a lot of key detail in this film and most importantly needed to be paid close attention. Some things may seem unclear but the more we watch the more we get accustomed to what's happening.

Several very lengthy fight sequences which this film possibly contains the best of the franchise. Two standouts. The first possibly is with Wick fending off the henchmen in Paris in oncoming traffic. We see a slew of vehicles passing by, with him maneuvering one by one. Also with the addition of the Tracker character and his dog. Very well shot and this lasted quite long but it's worth the watch.

The other is essentially the finale with Wick at the bottom of the flight of stairs along with the blind Caine character. The way they are both able to contract themselves and fend off these continuous henchmen fighting was thrilling.

Then the final showdown with Wick and Caine pacing back and forth was something was different and unexpected.

Overall if this is the final film of franchise, it definitely have ended on a high note.

My Impressions:

At almost three hours long, the fourth instalment in the "John Wick" franchise looked like it wanted to prove something. But insufficient suspense and oddly edited (for a production like this, anyway) sequences failed to impress. The story did get slightly better, but then again "Chapter 4" had an almost three-hour runtime to achieve that.

Countless scenes came across as over-commercialized and over-marketed. It took a lot away from a potentially intriguing storyline. There were more than a few instances when I felt "John Wick: Chapter 4" borrowed heavily from action-movie tropes that have since reached their expiration date.

I've long been a fan of Keanu Reeves and the man did not disappoint. His performance as the titular character was the only thing that made this movie compelling. Wick was seeking permanent escape, rather freedom, from the underworld. He was no longer interested in all the backstabbing, treachery, assassination, and espionage. But, leaving his line of work was easier desired than done.

Now we come to the baddies. Villains maketh the hero, as they say. In "John Wick: Chapter 4", all the baddies brought their A-game and delivered high-octane excellence. Their respective performances, stunts, and martial arts helped offset the creative limitations I observed in "Chapter 4".

Special shout-out to Scott Adkins who was brilliant, and rather under-rated, in the role of Killa. All his scenes were perfection. Much the same could be said for Bill Skarsgård as the Marquis Vincent Bisset de Gramont - including his incredibly natural French accent, sartorial style, and diabolical finesse.

Lance Reddick's presence in this movie made his current absence in our lives (and tinseltown) glaringly apparent. "Such is life," indeed. Rest in power, good sir.

Some of the elements I appreciated in the movie were the bulletproof Kevlar-lined suits, that outstanding Belgian Malinois, the rich décor and outfits on some of the characters (especially the Marquis), and of course everything Keanu Reeves brought to the fourth (and hopefully final) instalment in the "John Wick" movie series.

However, unnecessary fluff, unduly dramatic moments, a handful of contrived sequences, and a few discernibly slow stunt movements all weighed the movie down in ways that I, as a fan of this franchise, didn't quite expect.

Some other movies might have gotten away with such shoddy filmmaking, but not in this dojo, not in "John Wick: Chapter 4", where the movie's trailers and marketing pitches ended up outshining the final result.

The raison d'etre for some of the fights, including the Parisian traffic tussle did not quite check off all the right logic boxes. Anyway, that fight sequence had its moments. But the overhead single-take shot of Wick escaping through a single-floor apartment complex and his later 222-staircase rendezvous were both *chef's kiss* and expertly choreographed. That sentimental ending was a nice touch. Also, remember to catch that heartbreaking, but rather karmic, "John Wick 4" post-credits scene.

Hair-makeup and costume design were admirable. Art direction and set decoration were great. Stunts and VFX were noteworthy. Editing and sound effects were good. Musical scoring was amazing. Cinematography was exceptional. Screenplay was alright. Direction was quite good.

You already know how it is. Four movies, roughly 10 hours of watching people die and somehow it all lead up to this. Incredible world building, compounded by brilliant choreography, acting and script writing.

Every scene looks hyper real. Every gun shot, every punch, it's an art form. John Wick 4 neatly wraps up and incredible journey I didn't expect to go on. But I'm greatful I did.

It's the Die Hard of my generation and it's learned and matured so well. It's a visual spectical and I could watch it again and again. For me its a great start to cinema in 2023. It's got me excited for the next films I intend to see (Openheiner and MI).

Go see this movie and don't make the mistake I did, stay for the final scene after the credits!

On the positive side, cinematography is great, it is fast-paced and all the scenes and angles look gripping and impressive. Additionally, they really either shot most of it in Paris or made up a pretty convincing CGI version of it, so also looks authentic. Core actors are still doing great job portraying their characters, and some additional roles are also quite solid. Almost-3-hours runtime might be a bit much, but not too bad overall as it balances the story development with action scenes fairly well.

On the less positive, the fights are a lot less inventive than in previous installments - it's mostly "shoot them in the head" and that's about it. No killing people with a horse or a book or a carrot. Wait no the carrot is from another movie. Still sad though. The traffic scene around Arc de Triomphe was a nice exception, but even that was fairly monotonous. What makes it palatable is the fights are mixed with story development, but the fight themselves are quite boring.

Additionally, some characters are either not explained at all (and neither is their motivation) like Nobody, or disappear and leave the story lines dangling (like Akira), or just annoying and pathetic (like Marquis), which makes the whole story feel a lot less solid and definitive comparing to the previous installments (or at least comparing to chapters 1 and 2).

Overall it's a decent continuation, and a good evolution of the storyline, but somehow less exciting than the previous chapters.

A movie completely lacking of a storyline yet with a play time of 2h 45m.

The main character is shot hundreds of times at close range and yes we know he is wearing a cevlar suit, so do his enemies... and nobody thinks to aim for the head ?? And his enemies are wearing body armor yet are all killed with a single shot mr Wick is hit by speeding cars at least 6 times in 20 minutes, and unless i am mistaken cevlar doesn't protect against broken bones yet he gets up and walks away every time... even after falling from a 3rd story window onto a parked car and onto the street he gets up and walks away.

And last but not least he falls down 220 stairs and still gets up like nothing happened and climbs those stairs again

Come on! At least try to make it a bit credible A 5.5 at best.

I've never written a review on IMDB. I created an account solely with the intent to leave a review on this movie.

If you haven't watched any John Wick movies, it's one of the few movie franchises that don't juice all their ideas in one movie, create a hit, then release a sequel just to continue gaining revenue. Rather, the director proceeds to ideate in order to create a compelling story that harmonises with the previous movie.

The first three movies are great. But the fourth one is just out of the park. It's incomparable to the others, in terms of ideation, setting, cinematography, and performance. Simply phenomenal.

They say Keanu Reeves only said 380 words in the movie, but you wouldn't notice due to how compelling the story really is.

This movie thrives off of the action scenes; however, there are a handful of well-acted non action scenes.

John Wick 4 has truly set the bar for action movies in 2023. I'd even go as far as saying action movies in general.

Definitely recommend!

I went to check out the 4th installment of the John Wick installments with my family. Prior to watching the movie, i have read many positive reviews and went in expecting to be amazed! I have to say the movie surpassed all my expectations and completely blew me away with it's awesomeness and record breaking quality of action! Any upcoming movie in this genre will have to benchmark against this epic movie, as in my opinion, it is the best action movie i've ever seen! This movie is worthy of an Oscar and should be recognized for what it has produced to the audience! Well done to the cast!! Outstanding performances and I do hope they come back with a 5th installment and keep it going!

Hints were there for fans to pick and create a possible imagination of A New John Wick Chapter.

(Like, this quote "he didn't shoot".) And then at the end Marquis, didn't get the chance to take the shot. Eventually they took the "loaded gun". But the gun was loaded by Marquis with a bullet meant for Mr. Wick. Isn't it?

Opens an Opportunity for the next chapter I guess. Besides the tracker as a successor would be a great choice also.

All of this "loving husband" in the end, to get back to live a normal life? Touche!

But as a fan I'll never get bored to see John Wick in the middle of a whole different story.

If you peruse all of the reviews you will notice something. Nearly all of the bad reviews came a month after the release. These are folks who either downloaded/pirated the movie or bought the digital copy. Big mistake. John Wick 4 is a cinematic masterpiece built for the big screen. If you missed it in the theater then that's a huge loss. I personally saw the movie 11 times. And I will say that the IMAX version overdid it. The regular Digital version was calibrated perfectly. Seat D5, perfect. I don't understand the folks who say there wasn't a story. It built on the other movies. Ten stars.......

My take on John Wick Chapter 4: It lacked a compelling storyline, but compensated with visually stunning settings that transported me into a gritty underworld. However, there seemed to be an overindulgence in action sequences, showcasing masterful choreography that left me torn. On one hand, I appreciated the skill and precision involved, but on the other hand, it felt like an onslaught of relentless combat. Sometimes, too much of a good thing can be overwhelming, even if the quality remains exceptional. As they say, even an excess of something extraordinary can still be an excess.

Excessive.

I watched it without watching the three prequels, I have to say I'm very impressed by the gripping and tense action ,as well as top notch cinematography,just amazing. But after nonstopping sequences of gun fighting ,which are truly compact and leave you no chance to take a breathe, I'm quite tired. For reason that you know the protagonist would survive all those gruelling attacks and walk towards the final duel scene. When the first hour you get to see the exotic, cyberpunk and elegant touch of Japan,then it takes you to Berlin and the city of light. It's all about life and death,but also a complicated relationship between the old friends which involves trust and repay. A good film in total,worth the watch.

It's very overrated to my opinion, since the 1st John Wick, I have set myself not to pay attention to the storyline, but more into the cinematic CGI scenery, fight choreography, and character play.

Casts plays their character well, i give 8/10.

CGI cinematic scenery I have to say 8/10, Strength of John Wick enduring the torture of fights 5/10 (he's never claim as a superhuman).

Fights choreography is worse than previous sequel. 6/10.

What's the point of that blind character (Caine) if he can shoot ?? (6/10) Action movie that makes me laugh throughout the movies of too many ridiculous scenes. (6/10) Having all written, I have to say that one thing disappoint me the most is the fight choreography.

Honestly, I feel like the title to this review is enough. The fight scenes in this movie are the best they possibly could be. These are the kinds of stunts where I could see Tom Cruise watching this film in theaters and going, "Challenge accepted." The best word that comes to mind to describe the first few action set pieces is: "beautiful." I realize that what was happening on screen was very violent, but the movements and the methodical timing of them reminded me of an intricate dance, and I mean that in the highest of praise.

I feel like the word masterpiece gets tossed around a lot, but this movie is a masterpiece. I believe this will become the action movie to beat for a while.

No spoilers, just to say that it is worth a watch for action fans. Plot is weak, the film is really just a sequence of very long drawn out and unrealistic fight setpieces....which nevertheless are well shot. Unrealistic because the skill with which every single fighter in the movie (and there are literally hundreds if not thousands of them) can dodge bullets is ridiculous. Suffice to say, the ratio of gunshots on target at close range (within 1-2 metres) is about 1 in 10. Either the fighters are impossibly good at dodging bullets or else they have become so adept at unarmed combat that their gun firing skills have become nonexistent.

8.2 current rating, not even close, this is becoming ridiculous. Keanu is old and the fighting scenes are slow motion, very grandpa like.

The blind assassin chasing Keanu sees better than someone with 20/20 vision, the 1m distance gun fights and blocks are out of a fairytale.

The main audience for this type of movie are the same that pay to watch the Fast and Furious franchise.

This franchise needs to hire a younger actor, make the fight scenes a little more realistic and stop copying Power Rangers.

Do not waste time watching this movie if you want anything close to realism, watch this if you are bored and want to see kids creating fight scenes with multi million budgets.

Being a diehard keanu reeves admirer the sequel seems satisfying. The movie takes the thrilling saga of the legendary hitman to new heights. The story picks up right where the previous installment left off, delving deeper into the dark and mysterious underworld.

In this latest installment of the John Wick saga, Keanu Reeves once again proves that age is just a number and bullets are his preferred mode of communication. This time, our favorite dog-loving assassin takes on the High Table and their seemingly endless supply of relentless hitmen, making you wonder if there's a secret underground academy where they teach assassins to never, ever give up. As if killing the Elder wasn't impressive enough, John Wick goes globe-trotting from New York to Morocco, giving us action scenes that defy both physics and logic - and we're totally here for it.

10/10 best movie of the year I will definitely rewatch it on the weekend highly recommend Half of this review will be me gushing about the action. Wow. Just wow. I was in complete awe. There were multiple times I was both tearing up and laughing at how unbelievably amazing the fight scenes are. Now this is nothing new for the John Wick series. But for me, this is far and away the best action of the entire series I'm an action junkie and am repeatedly disappointed with action movies and their terrible fight scenes, filled with shaky cam, quick cuts and close-up shots (looking at you Snake Eyes and Mortal Kombat). Then I watch a John Wick movie and feel so spoiled, while also being baffled at why other action movies can't learn from this. The fights are so fast-paced yet completely clear and easy to follow.

This thing is a powerhouse in the action genre. Directed by Chad Stahelski and starring the one-face-to-rull-them-all Keanu Reeves, the film delivers an electrifying experience from the very first shot. One of the film's most impressive aspects is its action sequences, this thing DOESN'T HOLD BACK, the fight choreography is a work of art, expertly crafted and executed with precision,handcrafted by a stuntman himself, and that just about shows up every time there's punches in the frame, showcasing a keen eye for detail.

Also to my surprise, the film weaves a compelling narrative as it delves deeper into Wick's character, exploring the emotional toll of his violent lifestyle adding further depth to the world of assassination while also conveying the internal struggle of a haunted and determined Reeves.

As for the visuals this is a feast for the eyes that captures the gritty underworld in all its dark and atmospheric setting, boosted by a sleek production design making each frame a work of art.

This thing sets a new benchmark for the action genre, exceeding expecationts at every turn.... you should watch it.

In John Wick: Chapter 4, the performances of the cast, especially the one of Reeves, action scenes, screenplay, direction and filming angles, sound effects, cinematography, story, soundtrack, ending, and tone are all excellent. They are made with all perfection and passion.

Regarding the flaws, what I didn't like in John Wick: Chapter 4 is that in the story, there are some elements that made the story a little bit confusing and the plot missy. Also, I felt that the 169 minutes runtime was a little bit long for the plot.

But these flaws won't prevent me from giving the movie a high score because it is true that it has these two flaws, but at the same time, it has all the excellent features that I talked about above in the beginning of the review. So regarding the score, I gladly give John Wick: Chapter 4 9 out of 10.

I'll start with the bad bits as the good bits speak for themselves.

At part four I would like and expect some more character development. A deeping of the universe and expansion of the mythology. Wick Four really offers none of that. It has the Marquis, but who is he, how was he chosen, what's his background, give me something.

3 was good but repetative. The fights simply going on too long. I think if most people were honest when they looked at the running time of part 4 they would have been worried about this repeating. Thankfully the fights are long but they are kept interesting and different especially towards the closing of the story.

The style of the film is great, looks amazing and is super entertaining :) I would love to see a 5 if the can dive a little deeper.

This was my most anticipated movie of 2023, & John Wick: Chapter 4 (2023) both lived up & exceed all of my expectations. John Wick: Chapter 4 (2023) is not only the best movie of 2023, not only is it the best movie of the John Wick Franchise, but it is one of the greatest Action Movies of all time & is possibly the greatest movie that Keanu Reeves has ever done in his career.

The action & violence is outstandingly phenomenal! There are so many phenomenal standout action scenes, that I can't name all of them. One of my favorite scenes is where they are paying homage to Cowboy Bebop.

So if I didn't sell you enough with those statements, John Wick; Chapter 4 (2023) is a masterpiece of the action genre. It is the best movie of 2023 & I believe that no movie will even come close to besting it for the rest of the year!

What makes John Wick standout in a pretty crowded genre is the action choreography, the grittiness of the action and John's sheer force of will to eliminate every other guy in his way. We get the required goods here, Donnie Yen's addition to the cast also adds to the experience. He not only delivers the choreography but he does it with a flair that stands out (he's also helped along by playing a pretty unique character). There's all the requisite bangs and cracks and it still looks impressive and gives you what you want. (my favourite was the set piece with the birds eye view). The plausible deniability is pulled pretty thin (John Wick is apparently immune to damage after being hit by a car) but it was in the other movies as well, I just noticed it more.

John Wick didn't reintroduce us to Keeanu but it certainly helped catapult him back into the spotlight. John's a quiet character that relies more on his fists and his pistols to flip people to his point of view than his words. He's also an unkillable force of nature but both things are equally true. Keeanu still has the required gravitas to make our brooding master hitman tick and he's consistent with his performance in Chapter 4. Donnie Yen steals the show in my opinion, he's playing a more expressive and off-kilter character and he strikes a nice balance between serious and animated. Ian Mcshane returns as Winston, he's a great performer and he's got a magnetic screen presence. He's a needed anchor for this movie and he helps play up the stakes. Laurence Fishburne returns briefly as the Bowery King, he's doing the same kind of thing but he brings some badly needed levity. It was sad seeing Lance Reddick make his final appearance, he was always an underrated part of this franchise and he will be sorely missed. I wish we had gotten to see more of Rina Sawayama, she was great in her small amount of screen time. Wrapping up with Bill Skarsgard, he's fine as the Marquis but I wish he had been given more to chew on as the villain. He's a really capable actor and while he fits the bill, I couldn't help but feel he could have done more in Chapter 4 to make us really root for John in this battle, but he seemingly lacked the opportunity.

If you're being given a similar flick and you enjoyed the previous entries, you should be satisfied right? I left the theatre content but I was actually a little disappointed. I didn't think there was much new included here or I didn't feel like they did as much to try and raise the bar. I get why Chapter 3 was more contentious film than the previous entries but I'm a little surprised at all the unconditional love Chapter 4 has gotten. To me it felt like just more of the same from Chad Stahelski and his team. It's the same environments, the same kind of characters are introduced and minus a couple of small instances, the same kind of setpieces. Their output is sufficient here but I couldn't help but want more from Chapter 4.

John Wick: Chapter 4 delivers more of the same and if that's what you're primarily interested in, I think you'll leave the theatre satisfied. This is still a solid action movie, but some of the spellbinding affect melted away in this entry for me. The same kind of environments, characters and plot just left me shrugging my shoulders. It's not any better or any worse in almost any respect, I just noticed the machinations behind the curtain more and more. I still would be interested in another movie and hopefully The Continental TV show that's been in development for a while comes out soon. Going ahead, I hope they shake up the bag and bring something new to the mix, they need it more than they realize. Check it out if you're interested but if you haven't jumped on board the franchise's hype train yet, you're okay letting this one go by.

Thinking about this movie I'll tell you what I realized about it. We're basically watching poor John Wick get tortured for 3 hours. Shot at, beat, kicked, thrown, run over by cars, trucks, and fat Russians. By the end the guy is basically beat to death. Is this the story of a warrior or is it some kind of metaphorical journey through the circles of hell? I don't know. To me, it was the story of a man who has too much talent being used for that talent until it was all gone, and then being tossed aside when it was clear he had nothing left to give. I think that can kind of tell you what the story of the High Table is all about, it's the story of the abuse of man. It tells us how the rich and powerful use people up then stick them in graves with happy go lucky slogans on them. The irony of John Wick is that he knows what he's doing, who he works for, and how corrupt it all is but he doesn't care because he thinks they're all going to end up exactly where he does.

As everybody knows by know, or rather, as everybody who knows who John Wick is, you can expect so much action, gun fight, knife fight and blood shed. The story of Baba Yaga continues in this fourth chapter. I do like this one better than the previous chapter. Though I also find it a little ridiculous when he kept rolling down the stairs like a ball after getting kicked. I was thinking, "Seriously? What are you? A ball?! Stop rolling down the stairs!" And I also find it really weird that those people at the club kept on dancing although they're watching a fight unfolding right before their very eyes. That's odd, at least for me.

Ridiculous. Bullet proof clothing? Really?? And that stair scene. Really? I realize there is a certian amout of suspention of dissbelief when it comes to most movies but this one is off the charts. When I seen 8.3 stars on IMDB I was excited to go see it. I almost walked out and I can never remember doing that before. Little to no real plot. Just shooting and fighting to the point of boredom and I loved the first one. I like a good action movie but come on. I would not go to see John Wick 5 which I am sure will be out there Just like Fast and Furious 57 or whatever number thier up to.

It appears there is no real thought anymore in Hollywood. Wayyy too mant sequals with no original ideas for new movies. I guess thats why I rarely go to the movies anymore.

John Wick has stayed true to what it always has been from JW1 to JW4. Full throttle action - fighting, gun play, swords, assassins, muscle cars and badass dogs! The locations and filmography are top notch! Fast paced for an almost three hour action film. You just cannot turn away from it all. Not much on the dialogue for this one, but it provides just enough juice there to give some substance outside of the choreographed fights and shots to the head. A strong, robust cast that knows how to play their position; Delivering a quality movie any action buff can and will appreciate. Grab your pop corn, get the snacks, turn up the volume, lean back and enjoy. You are in for a ride. Happy hunting!

The usual John Wick. The guy is armour plated. Even more than usual. He meets some old friends. Some good some bad. The same with new friends. The action very rarely stops. Some impressive room to room views from above towards the end. What impressed me the most was the similarities of him on the run at the end to the escape run of the Warriors trying to get back home to Coney Island. This time they are trying to get John before his duel with the head of the high table. The lady DJ calling out the news and the guns after them. This was a surprise. Don't know if there is a coupling here but Watch it and tell me I'm wrong .

This is a good action movie with likeable characters, innovative camera work with amazing lightening. I can see people saying there's too much neon-cyberpunk feel to it and that's true but rather than looking mishmash they blend well together and looks striking.

As someone who didn't get to watch this in theaters I watched it on OLED TV and it just looks phenomenal, pallets are striking, it got tones of depth and contrast.

Action sequences are a mixed bag for me, although camera work is steady, zoomed out so we get to see how things are being executed in respect with how things are moving in background with few cuts and few camera angle changes which creates coherent scenes.

Sequences felt a bit stretched out and looked too much choreographed, lack of uncertainty and felt like people waiting for things to happen just to move on to the next scene. Falling from second or from stairs guy just brushes up and get back to action. All suits are now bullet proof forgetting bullets carry lot of momentum and hurt like nothing regardless, here they just use suit like shield which looks laughable and there are many more nonsense scenes like these.

"John wick" character is the one which I most disliked, he has no motive, talks couple lines in couple different languages which certainly doesn't look cool.

"John Wick: chapter one" is still my most re-watched movie of the series but I think after all it's flaws this part is has move re-watch value than other parts.

It should be fairly obvious by this point that if you loved the previous John Wick entries, then you're going to love chapter 4.

The John Wick franchise is hands down one of the most consistently well-made action franchises of all time. Just like the previous three films, John Wick 4 contains some of the most exciting and perfectly executed action scenes of modern cinema, all of which take place in gorgeous, gothic, neon-drenched set pieces. Highlights include the nunchucks fight, the amazing overhead shootout, and the epic staircase shootout at the finale. Badass stuff.

The new additions of Donnie Yen, Hiroyuki Sanada, Scott Adkins, and Bill Skarsgård were all great. The only new addition I was a bit iffy on was Shamier Anderson. He wasn't terrible by any means but his character did feel a bit underwhelming in comparison to the rest of the new cast. Donnie Yen in particular was just fantastic. I loved his character and the unpredictability that came with him. Ip Man rarely disappoints.

As much as I did enjoy John Wick 4 and was fully entertained during the entirety of its nearly three hour run time, looking at the film objectively, John Wick 4 is the only entry in the franchise that began to feel like it was starting to run low on new ideas. This chapter didn't expand the world-building of the John Wick universe nearly as much as its predecessors did.

And as much as I enjoyed all the action, I don't know if there was any action sequence in this one that I could put above some of the other sequel highlights such as the underground corridor shoot-out in chapter 2 or the incredible opening in chapter 3.

I will say however that the way this film ended was perfect. So perfect in fact that I feel like it would be a massive disservice to the franchise if this series decided to continue. I'm sure it will because Hollywood will milk any potential cash cow to death at this point. But if the franchise ended right now with this 4th chapter, then the legacy of this tetralogy would be fondly remembered as some of the finest action movies of the 21st century.

There are some good scenes. Especially the battle filmed from above. Very smooth camera work.

Shamier Anderson is quite good. I hope to see him again soon.

Skarsgard is fine as the proverbial French arrogant p..k to which he adds a nice oily venomous touch. Slightly disturbing is his completely failed French accent which sounds much more Germanic.

But Skarsgard is no Nyqvist. He lacks depth. That's not fatal for a John Wick movie but imo the first installment was the best for its intensity and the charisma of the senior foe.

More troublesome, the fights in the first half of the movie aren't good. The opponents wait patiently to be shot and Reeves is much slower and less dynamic than in the previous movies. The camera manages much better to hide that for the fights in the second half though. Some battle scenes are too long.

Lance Riddick is sorely missed. RIP. He was such a fine actor and a perfect fit for his role in this franchise.

"Our business here now is concluded". That is a wise choice indeed.

Depending on its theatrical run, John Wick 4 is slated to be the final film in the John Wick franchise. That being said, John Wick: Chapter 4 definitely stands out as the most hard-hitting action film in the series and a satisfying conclusion to one of the best action franchises in recent years. The optimist in me however still hopes there'll be a John Wick 5 or at least a spin-off franchise. The only minor complaint I have is that John Wick 4 doesn't have the same elements of world-building lore that made the previous films so engaging but John Wick 4 more than makes up for it with pure elements of non-stop action and impressive fight choreography which make sure to push Wick to his absolute limit. The action is so intense at times that I was actually felt out of breath while watching Wick battle through multiple waves of minions and assassins. John Wick 4 includes an excellent cast of heroes and villains, including Donnie Yen and Scott Adkins, who are all phenomenal in the film. All of the above deliver a delicious cinematic action feast that you don't want to miss out on while the movie's still in theaters.

Now don't get me wrong I love the John Wick franchise, it's what I would call James Bond on crack (with better writing and visuals) BUT this one just didn't hit like the other three.

I'm not sure if it was the runtime or just that there wasn't any memorable kills but it felt like same crap different day.

I do have to give credit where it's due, which is the birds-eye view scene, *chefs kiss* this was stunning to look at. No fault on my boy Keanu Reeves, knowing the amount of effort he puts into this movies really shines in this one. But the story wasn't interesting enough for me, the villain was good but also bad.

Bill Skarzgård, is very much someone I would like to strangle in this film but again nothing very compelling from his character. I needed more from this, being the last movie, I was hoping for something to think about after the film was over but to be honest it just wasn't there.

Maybe the other three were just better in comparison and they struggled to "up the ante" yes I know, he kills many people in this one (I think it worked out to be nearly a kill every minute) but nothing really "stood out" for me.

I wasn't completely disappointed by this film, and it does okay to wrap up the storyline.

RIP Lance Reddick you will forever be in the hearts of all John Wick fans.

The best action movie I have ever seen in my life I recommend it for all the action scenes, the sound effects and especially the cinematic effects of movement around the shot excellent 👌 with the lighting effects of the locations it was crazy.the best of the franchise, the length is about 3 hours, it doesn't feel heavy, it's the best, the scenes in Tokyo are very enjoyable, the new weapons, WOW very cool, great that they include new martial arts actors, it was super to see them fight, the change of focus that the character suffers is incredible, the action exceeded my expectations, you really have to see it. This movie is a work of art.

Spoilers: I understand that the saga had to end at some point, but that doesn't mean Wick had to die. People say that in order for wick to truly find peace and freedom he had to be dead. I find it is absurd to believe that in order to find peace we have to die, death is not the answer. Killing wick to give him peace, is like saying everyone who has loss a loved one will not find peace until they die....that is false! Pain hurts but we eventually find a way and life goes on. We wish a happy life to those who we love, John's wife probably thought the same. She would have wanted a John Wick who left all the past behind and found meaning in his new life without her. Instead, the writers didn't give wick time for closure and to fully overcome his grief for her. It was just killing, killing, killing until he died too. At least they should have made wick's death a mystery like the dark knight rises. I truly hope this was not the end for such an incredible character.

I do not understand the appeal of this franchise has to people and the high ratings. And because of that, I decided to watch the film. What a mistake, what a waste of time.

The script is super swallowed, every scene and dialogue it's a cliche, and the acting is so stiff. Fighting scenes seem to follow the same pattern. Keanu fights like a 56-year-old man. Maybe it would be better to use a stand man every time Keanu had to fight because even to an untrained eye it looks too slow.

I am going to forget this film really fast the same way I forgot the previous two. Only the first one had something to offer for a film of this genre.

John Wick 4 expands the run time to 2 hours and 49 minutes and shows action fans one can never have enough of a good thing.. All of the stylish, hyper violence and intensity of the previous films is here, simply taken to greater length. John Wick finally finds a way to defeat the high table.

Set in Berlin, Germany, Osaka, Japan, Paris, France and New York City, New York. One of the most intense, visceral action movies ever made. A fitting end to a great action franchise and one hell of an action movie. Four stars for the action choreography. Three stars overall as a movie. Highly recommended for all action fans.

Once again John Wick delivers what we want, a scene to scene action packed thrill ride. However its run time is far too long, leaving us with elongated action scenes that could have been cut shorter.

The film really does drag you into its fast paced and violent world, yet keeps you adrenaline going so long that it becomes tiring.

It has a satisfying ending and does a great job at keeping the legend of John Wick alive. I would however take a happy break from this franchise even though I have looked forward to every instalment.

Lets face it, we know most of the cast and they are amazing and skilful as usual and the new members of the cast really do add a lot which is great.

If you have enjoyed the previous instalments then you will most likely love this film, but if you are not really a fan then an almost 3 hour Wick film is most likely not for you.

Enjoy or avoid, just respect the art.

Sometimes when you have high expectations for a movie, probably you could be disappointed. However this new chapter on the John Wick saga takes you into a new dimension of action. Some of these action sequences are very original, you can note a hard work to make a difference respect other action movies. The electronic soundtrack is an excellent complement for the action. I recommend to see the movie in a IMAX cinema, this way you'll experience all the action details and the amazing sound. I usually see movies on IMAX and I call tell you the John Wick sound is absolutely amazing respect others movie in the same format.

John wick chapter 4 is definitely the best action movie in John wick series. It is not only the best movie in the series but also the best Action movie ever made.

Overall John wick series has been the most beautiful master piece of Action movies.

John wick chapter 4, is a masterpiece from beginning of the film to end and to post credit scene.

On a personal level i may not be a fan of the ending of the film, but i was prepared for that kind of ending of this movie.

I Would like to see Mr. Wick alive in the next part.

Wil wait for bellerina and the continental to see what comes next in this movie series. I am hoping to see John wick in action. If this is the end, then Miss you BABA YAGA.

This by itself is a pretty decent movie not as good as Chapter 2 but about as good as the other 2. However, the impression that I get from the first 3 John Wick movies is that he doesn't die and is incredibly skilled. In this though he dies after getting shot 3 times which he survives similar things in the other movies. Because of this it just feels like it was rushed and just missed the point of the rest of the franchise. The CGI was unimpressive but the last time I watched a new film it was Avatar: The Way Of Water so it might just be my expectations being set too high. On the bright side the extras were much better than in the previous films.
