How bad can fight scenes be?

It depends - they can be poorly done, or they can be poorly implemented into the movie.

In this case, it's a bit of the former, and all of the latter.

More specifically - the fight scenes have a few seconds of brilliance here and there, but in general they are mediocre, repetitive, and drawn out to the point of becoming boring halfway through each of those scenes.

Filming and editing are equally uninspired, only doing the basic task of capturing stereotypical action choreography and worn out effects.

Even worse, the action gets in the way of what little story there is; this film has moments when a coherent and convincing tale is showing through - like there's an actual movie, desperately trying to get out.

But to no avail; inevitably yet another endless tedious action scene will have you reach for the forward key.

Many missed opportunities, like the brilliant idea of that one 'unique' hitman, which then was so poorly executed.

Action movies, fight scenes, they've been mastered ages ago; of course by many of the better martial arts movies from the East, or Western films like Kill Bill.

What they have in common is a sense for proportion, balance, timing and rhythm - this flick only piles one cheap thrill on top of another, and another, and so on to the point of exhaustion.

It's unfortunate the creators chose to completely abandon the recipe of the first two John Wick movies, which were very decent.

On a positive note: John Wick 3 was even worse re. All of the above; but a heavy dose of confirmation bias might have made the creators of this sequel ignore its predecessors' obvious shortcomings.

Gun-fu is still cool, but nothing new or interesting is added to it. And when the movie barely has any substance outside of gun-fu, it feels really thin. The previous movies in the franchise at the very least brought interesting and new angles in each instance. In this movie, the biggest "news" is that another swede is playing the main antagonist. Skarsgård is brilliant, but it's not enough.

The action sequences are amazing, and should bring viewers. But it is not a movie I'd watch again.

Also, when pretty much the first thing that happens is that Charon is killed off, it's pretty much a "meh" movie after that.

Pros:
Gun-fu
Bill Skarsgård and. Donnie Yen are fantastic.


Cons:
nothing new, even gun-fu is getting old
no real substance to the story.

Unlike the previous three chapters, this is the worst chapter in the John Wick franchise. For more than 3 hours, John Wick was like a superhero who killed everyone without any difficulty. This movie reminds me of the 70s 80s with the Terminator, Rambo,... when the main character was simply "unstoppable". Besides, John Wick doesn't seem to understand the danger to himself. He rushed out and shot and killed as if to prove that he was just a "killer". Then the blind character played by Donnie Yen is also like a superhero when he can walk freely, use swords, shoot people with guns as if his eyes are still bright??? I couldn't understand the plot throughout the length of the movie. This is definitely the most wasted 3 hours of my life.

Yes, I watched all 4 movies.

No, I didn't like any of them.

Yes, that makes no sense.

No, I can't explain.

Somehow, I hoped the next iteration of this series would be different. Have more story. Make more sense. But all 4 movies are well made fight scenes with a bit of story added to make it into a movie.

Now it did my head in how these movies get such high rating. Then it dawned on me that kids these days love watching others play games like Roblox or Call of Duty. This movie is tailor-made for these audiences.

The movie feels like a game with a bit of story with a bit of acting and then you fight. Kill all the bad guys from level 1 and unlock the story-scene toward level 2 until you get to the end boss.

So my 4-stars are based on this being a movie. It's slick and looks good, so that's 4 stars. But the other ingredients a movie needs, like acting, storyline and character development, are non-existent.

This fourth chapter, more than the previous ones, is overrated. The plot is non-existent and childish, the fights are ridiculous: if you get into the habit of watching your enemies during action scenes you almost want to stop watching it. Enemies who wait their turn fussing around without meaning while the protagonist does his bidding. Men of 80 kilos thrown into the air like not even in Avengers. The protagonist who is run over, hit by bullets, falls from the fourth floor of a building and yet continues just a little tired. Even if it were a fantasy it would be ridiculous. And then where is the plot? The ultimate meaning of the story? Perhaps authors should watch films like Leon or Nikita sometime to understand how these kinds of stories are told. In my opinion, it's a film that can be watched just out of boredom and that doesn't deserve the compliments it has received. But on the other hand, it is the public who decides, and if the public appreciates this kind of film then the world of cinema will continue to offer them to us.

First of all: Perhaps I should have watched the previous John Wick movies first in order to find a value in this movie's plot. Well, I didn't watch the prequels. So, perhaps I may be missing the true core value of this flick. Who knows ...

First, the plot summary: People are getting killed over and over and over again. That's it. End of story. Period.

Yet, for what cause do they fight? So, they just hate each other?? ... or love each other? Hundreds of them? And they all just die in seconds? Where did all these fighters get their training from? How did they all master such training if they all die on a fast lane in the end?

For John & friends it doesn't seem sufficient to just immobilize their enemies and continue to deal with another person. Oh no, way off the mark! They compulsively must return to every seriously wounded person and finish him/her off while already "serving" their next slaughter victim ...

Actually, while watching the movie I couldn't fail to get the impression that I was barely audiencing a rendition of some gamer who is playing a first person shooter computer game. The plot didn't have any deeper sense than that at all. No goal to achieve other than killing everybody until John & friends were the last men standing. During the fight scenes I was from time to time looking out for a game score in the corners of the screen.

Considering the stunts: The flick was advertised for its great fight scenes. So, well - I came expecting ... great fight scenes. But what did I get: CGI fights. Animated computer characters fighting animated computer characters. How much more boredom can be portrayed than barely watching computer characters fight each other.

Anyone glorifying the fight seens here in his/her reviews: So, you don't recognize a plain CGI rendering when you're watching it? Really?? - So, you didn't recognize all the unnatural character movements during fights or shootings? You didn't recognize or realize that the whole Place Charles de Gaulle scene was a computer animation with no man nor dog nor any car being recorded in reality? You plainly have been watching a bloody computer rendering on a large screen and failed to recognize??

These unnatural rubber toy, superball movements of the CGI characters during fight scenes kept me wondering if I had accidentally visited one of those dreadful poorly computer animated Marvel flicks.

Well, I guess it should be clear to everyone that no-one ... I repeat: NO-ONE by far could have survived any of these fight scenes. John Wick would have died multiple times: Fully hit by a car, but suffering no harm, huh? Falling down the stairs hundreds of meters, but he's fine and immediately continuing to fight. Or he's crashing into another car unbelted. The car is broken, yet John is left uninjured - yeah, sure ...

Honestly, I'm a person who wants to believe. Yet, there is a limit that's being reached when it comes to a certain degree of incredibility. Now, that limit of credibility has by far been exceeded by this flick.

Next, the musical score was a true disappointment. It didn't convey any emotion. It just played some metal licks, being strung together, or boring loops that have been played.

By the way: What sense does it make for this decade's professional radio station to play vinyl records or multi-track tapes from a tape recorder?

Last but not least: Character depictions were shallow. Since the musical score failed to support the characters, I failed to feel for any of them. ... One of John's friends died? Well, OK, fine. Next.

For me, this movie was a true disappointment.

Another epic and boring franchise ending, good! It's becoming more and more ridiculous kind of like the Fast and Furious series. Where do I start?

predictable plot line written by a 5 year old. Ex friend ex colleague gets killed/daughter survives/family blabla/cocky boss gets killed.


John fights a Caine, a blind man. Does not manage to kill him. The man is BLIND. John has the advantage (he can see and is a killer) yet still cannot win.


John gets hit by a car at least 4-5 times. Survives.


John fights off 30 bad guys in close combat. All armed and none manages to shoot his head. Survives.


John jumps out the window from the 3rd floor. Lands on van. Survives.


John travels in Paris with a fast bike. Somehow he cannot go to Sacré coeur with it. He has to stop and climb the 200 steps. He needs to learn how to ride like Tom Cruise.


Akira disappears in the middle of the movie. Seeks revenge for her father. Why not make her appear at the end and together they all fight the bad guys? At least it would have been more believable then some 58 year old man kicking ass to 50 deadly men.


Tired of movies using real cities but totally disregarding the reality of the city:
° shootouts in the middle of the streets of Paris and people barely notice.

° car chase in Arc de triomphe (a busy roundabout) and cars don't stop or slow down. It's a busy place and cars would slow down!

° empty Paris and sacré coeur despite 100s of rounds being shot. Apparently Paris (the busier tourist place on earth) is empty at 6 AM and Parisians are deaf.

Movie should have been 25 minutes shorter.

If you want to see an aging actor move just a bit slower, and his enemies wait to be hit by him, then you're in for a treat! I think audiences are so used to seeing a guy run up to Wick to try and punch him with their gun instead of using it from afar that it no longer looks ridiculous, which it is. Also, apparently, he's bulletproof, and can grab/roll any number of bad guys he wants to.

The movie long climax scene grows old fast as John Wick now has unlimited stamina, can almost never be shot, recovers from all injuries, and is now in God Mode. And as anyone knows, God mode removes any sense of difficulty, suspense, or accomplishment. This movie is a joke. If the protagonist is never in danger, and can never really be hurt, there's no tension or drama. Don't waste your time.

Can't say I was intrigued by the story, no real twists and frankly boring. - The fights quality are quite on the lower end.of.the spectrum and doesn't really stand out.

The movie didnt contain any storyline that will.captovate one, its fairly predictable from the start, there are a few exceptions throughout the film were one would be intrigued, but the movie itself seems to be a low budget movie with very low quality stunts.

I wouldn't recommend the movie, even the cinema was fairly small, since not many are attending to watch.

Long, and painful to watch. - but surprisingly highly rated throughout the web.

FYI : THIS MOVIE IS FOR 15 YEARS OLD KIDS WHO LIKE PLAYING GUNS WITH HIS FRIENDS.

Are you kidding me this movie have 7.8 rating.

I belive most of them give rating is 10 years old boy who like gun playing with his friends.

This movie is so unrealistic and the story are very boring and childist

i remember john wick 1 has best story and action.

But after that, the story getting worst and worst.

I dont know what point story of this movie.

ITS ACTION MOVIE BUT AFTER 30 MINUTE YOU GETTING BORING.

And typicall hollywood movie, 1 battalion army with AR-15 can't defeate john wick with only hand gun.

Hahahaahahahhah.

SISU movie much better than this.

After watching the first hour of the film I considered watching something else and I regret not doing so. The third movie had fight scenes that went on too long and I should have recognized the signs that this movie was going to take it to a whole new level. Needless to say, this movie has a lot of mind numbing action, far too much, and not enough character interaction like the previous movies. Movies 1 & 2 had a good plot, 3 had kind of a plot, this movie has barely anything.

JW4 became a repetitive third person shooter with endless ammo and bullet sponge enemies, some almost as invincible as John Wick himself. There was one scene with interesting cinematography but by that point who really cares. The Animals nod/homage/blatant rip off was odd to say the least. The ending, meh.

A good editor and writer could have introduced the Osaka characters and done something interesting. Instead it is just a mindless 2.5+ hours of shooting, punching, throwing, stabbing, grappling and falling.

It's time to knock this on the head, I thought it couldn't be as bad as III, but wrong again. No coherent story, a blind assasin you could just stand still and shoot in the head, bullet proof men in full body armour and men in suits that your not allowed to take head shots at. John teleports around the world with no explanation. How does this get a 7.7 rating? Something fishy going on here. Why was he chasing 3 Arabs on horseback shooting at them? Who knows I don't. This series started as an entertaining tale and has devolved into a series of set pieces that we've seem many times before and a ludicrous disjointed mess of a plot.

Not sure why they had to make the movie just under 3 hour long. The story line is just simple but they had to make the action scenes unnecessarily long. This could easily take just 2 hours max.

The first 2 movies are pretty good with some realistic plots and actions. This time it was just ridiculously unrealistic. The scene at Arc de Triomphe was just silly. So were the other action scenes. The fight coreography was not bad though.

I'm glad they finished off the franchise. Not sure how they would milk it any longer. I like the John Wick character but seems like the writers just run out of good ideas.

Action that is too stupid and defies any sense of reality. This is basically like watching someone play a video game. No real story, no depth of character and boring bits between the action scenes. The boring bits must have been an attempt to give the film some depth but failed to do so.

I don't know where to start with this mindless drivel so I'm not going to list all the reasons why this film is so bad. Such a shame as the first two films hit the mark.

I like action film and I get that it's not supposed to be real but there has to be some sense of reality so the viewer can engage with the danger faced by the main character. You have to care about him but it fails to provide any emotional connection to anyone. This is Tom and Jerry on steroids.

I'd watch the Equaliser movies as a reminder of how it should be done.

I did not watch till the end. The level of ridiculous hit new heights in the Paris car chase. I could not have cared less on how it ended by this point.

After three thrilling and action-packed films, I had high hopes for "John Wick: Chapter 4" to continue delivering something fresh and captivating. Unfortunately, this film turned out to be a complete letdown and a sudden decline in quality. From the story to the action and even the performances, everything lacked innovation and felt like a weak rehash of the previous movies.

The film's beginning promised a tale of revenge and intense action, but it failed to deliver. The plot became convoluted and overly complicated for its own good. New characters were hastily introduced and lacked proper development, resulting in shallow interactions and a lack of emotional investment. Moreover, the film lost the charm and mystery of its titular character, John Wick, becoming a mindless and bloody sequence of fights.

The action itself was dull and devoid of innovation, making it feel like a mere repetition of what we've seen before. The fight scenes lacked creativity and failed to evoke any excitement or adrenaline. Even the inclusion of new cast members, such as Donnie Yen and Bill Skarsgård, couldn't salvage the film from its lackluster execution.

Furthermore, the pacing of the film was uneven, with moments of unnecessary exposition and prolonged sequences that added little to the overall story. The narrative felt disjointed and struggled to maintain a cohesive flow, leaving the audience disconnected and disengaged.

While the previous John Wick films managed to strike a delicate balance between style, substance, and visceral action, "John Wick: Chapter 4" missed the mark completely. It felt like a cash grab, relying on the success of its predecessors without offering anything new or memorable.

In conclusion, "John Wick: Chapter 4" is a major disappointment in the film franchise. It lacks originality, fails to deliver compelling action, and falls short in terms of storytelling and character development. Fans of the series will be left unsatisfied and longing for the excitement and quality that defined the earlier films.

Some really good action scenes can't overcome the hurdles of overconcoluted lore and a story which a 5 year old would write.

The fist movie worked in its simplicity with impactful action, you could nearly feel the punches watching it. By the fourth movie its just an unwanted parody of itself.

Where you can't help yourself but laugh at the ridiculous scenes, which seem to be in there for the rule of cool - for me it didn't work. The stakes are just gone if seemingly fall damage is disabled for the main character for the hundredth time or you can see the random mob encounters in the background just waiting until its there time to get shot.

John Wick 4 is an insultingly misdirected piece of art that is chock full to the brim with overwrought and under energised action sequences. Casting the legendary Donnie Yen as a blind man that is sometimes blind and sometimes not blind is offensive and shows disrespect. The failure to properly address all the issues in the previous three films, in addition to confusing the structure and hierarchy of the high table leads to damaging the franchise as a whole. Keanu Reeves is appalling in this movie - his character does not have one interesting line of dialogue or emotion and his movements are slow and unrealistic. This whole world of John Wick needs to stop, the waters are too muddied and everybody looks tired.

One-sentence summary: Tired of the constant pursuit by The High Table, John Wick sets out to defeat the Marquis and secure his freedom.

I never thought there would come a day when I got tired of seeing John Wick slaughter his enemies by the hundreds, and although that day isn't quite here yet, it's coming closer. Wick's revenge-fueled rampage in the first film seems to have morphed into more of a survival effort as the franchise has progressed. So even if there are more kills in chapter four (as there should be with a runtime of 169 minutes), they lack the personal edge. What this movie does offer, however, is several attention-grabbing set pieces, pleasantly odd antagonists, and persistently elaborate fight choreography. I'm usually pretty good about suspending my disbelief, and they've previously established that Mr. Wick can take extensive beatings, but some of the punishment he's able to incur in this film while remaining relatively unfazed was nothing short of absurd. If this marks the end of the road for the Baba Yaga, regardless of my indifference to this movie, Keanu Reeves should be proud of what he was able to accomplish with the series as a whole.

What a complete waste of nearly 3 hours. A flimsy story that was fleshed out with soooo many fight scenes I was barely paying attention. The highlight was the dog peeing on a dead guy. If you read this and like good acting a great story mixed in with some action don't watch this movie. Oh apparently a good review requires more words which like John Wick 4 is a complete waste of my time, must be the new norm. So seeing as I don't have anything else positive to say about the movie, let's hope they don't do a John Wick 5. Oh wait I see it may be in production. Well for me I won't be lining up to watch this snooze fest.

If you want to waste 2,5 hours of your life watching a series of complete unrealistic shooting scenes with no plot, this is your chance. They had tons of posibilities, money, time and expectations to make this a great movie. Instead they give us nothing but shooting and a cheap plot. Like another reviewer said it; it's like playing a video game on «easy»-mode. Unrealistic scenes, effects and, again, useless plot. Some of the main charaters seems hard to understand the necessity of and the hitmens (or whatever you call the guys that shows up out of nowhere with a gun) miss the target standing 2 meters away from John. I'd rather watch the first movie again a couple of times in stead of this rubbish. Please don't waste your precious time on this.

This review is not made for a popularity contest, something people tend to do to negative reactions about stuff they like, is to portray it on themselves and start lashing out. I didnt expect the movie to score an average 8,3, and I'm sorry, I really didn't like the movie.

I used to love john wick as a series. 1 was the best, 2 was good, 3 was already too much action for me and not as fun. 4 is just on steroids, its got almost no story, its less believable than before, and some of the acting is just so flippin cringe. I left the cinema after paying 20 euros. My opinion is not at all important when you like a 2-hour long fight scene with some cringe conversation. But if you like to watch something with story related content, or something that adds to the world building of the john wick universe, like 1 and 2 did, then I don't recommend the watch.

Like the bad sunset of one's career and this series is finally brought to an end (I hope)! So much nonsense in one well rated movie. I still don't understand who gave good reviews to such a bad movie. Without a story, without emotions, without any empathy, John Wick "refuses to die", using a suit to protect himself from bullets, defying all the laws of physics. Something like this is not even seen in fairy tales. An action film in which the old Chinese model of running on air and walls seems quite realistic. I guess the team tried to imitate the Matrix trilogy in some way and failed miserably in the attempt. A total disappointment.

This movie is mostly about fighting, but fighting often looks so bad and underdeveloped. They should have used more cuts, or hire the main character who can fight more dynamically. What's the point of doing your own stunts, if they look weak and slow.

Often bad guys just stand in place and do nothing, waiting for John to turn to them and kill them. Other times then run out of cover towards John while having a gun. It looks so bad, like in a B-movie, and definitely not believable. Bullets do nothing, and yet everyone uses them for some reason.

Keanu Reeves accent and catchphrases like "I need a gun" sound forced and over-acted.

Good parts: Location shots and scene design, amny scenes look futuristic and cool.

So I was hoping this one was gonna deliver more in terms of story and character but sadly no. All the same beats as before, all the same tropes from the previous films and the only thing holding it together is Keanue and Donnie Yen.

The world of John Wick is a small world, everyone in it is an assassin and that makes assassins mundane and boring. The movie takes place all over the world and characters teleport at a moments notice making the world feel even smaller.

John is not a very interesting character, he was in the first one where we got to know him, but now that we do know him there isn't much going on. His persistence and skill is the only thing interesting about him and that's not enough to carry a movie this long.

The whole "High table" thing is so lame. They really don't know what to do with it and now that the series has been all over the world and killed everything that moves 100 times over the threat of the HT is pretty much like being scared of the IRS.

I hope they keep making films with this level of skill and love but for christ sake, put some effort into the scripts!!!

A good video game perhaps, but it strains imagination at this point, too many deaths, too many Continental Hotels, too many great fighters in them. I could not believe what kind of a world we would be living in with the thousands of assassins that are staying at these hotels, not to mention there are other cities besides five that have Continental Hotels, how about Los Angeles, Chicago, Miami, Pittsburgh, Philadelphia, then Africa having Egypt, thus Cairo. Kenya, South Africa, let's not forget South America and Mexico. We have violence enough in this world, so I am really disappointed in Keanu Reeves for taking the fantasy too far, in retrospect, the original was enough. We are really over ran with continuing sagas, it's like it's all professional wrestling, Seen it, only so many times can you see it again, just changing the title slightly.

If Parabellum was sketchy, Chapter 4 was simply boring. The acting was not convincing, fight scenes were so drawn out, men in suits didn't die when they were shot at point blank range multiple times, and above all the story line is extremely weak.

The action in Berlin had people partying all the while fighting and guns were going on all around them. Dystopian maybe but this was way beyond plausibility.

Honestly, I've seen better shoot 'em up games where at least the action and objective is more credible. As for Wick himself, it wasn't s stunning performance compared his first two appearances.

A deconsicrated mess. Despite Donny yen trying to carry the entire movie on his back it ends up feeling like a 2hr long video game Cutscene with a short movie at the end. Everyone looks aweful and tired the acting and writing just doesn't hold up. Go play max Payne 3 with mods it's more enjoyable than watching this.

Poor Keanu lumbers from scene to scene with nothing to say no real story like they forgot to give him anything memorable to say or do.

Re-watching this for the first and last time is just painful it's a very nice looking movie but the pacing is in slow motion all the action is telegraphic.

It's not that I couldn't imagine there being four John Wick movies after I saw the first one, all those years ago, it's just I would have imagined them being straight-to-DVD Steven Seagal flicks, not global blockbusters.

But such was the charm of the first film: a dumb action movie much the same as any Jean-Claude Van-Damme video, but with first-rate world-building, care, attention and charm, and the best fight scenes seen in years. The two following films expanded the world but the story got worse, and here we are at last at the finale.

More than the others, this one has too many extraneous new characters introduced, padding out the screen-time and sidelining John Wick from his own movie. These are mostly fairly likeable and decently acted; they're just unnecessary, and clutter up the story with side quests no-one going in wanted to see.

The weakest actor is the Japanese girl playing Akira, although actually she may well be the best of them at performing the fight moves, which, early on especially, are nothing to write home about, look very obviously choreographed and rehearsed and go on much too long. The film could have been cut by up to an hour and it would have been better for it.

Keanu is looking a little stiff and frail and maybe ill, and there are long stretches in which he is not on the screen. And most of the time when he is he just stands around silent looking apologetic. By this point in the story, he's just depicted as an invulnerable superhero, and so the dramatic tension has greatly diminished: though some of the later fight scenes are inventive and well-plotted, they have no emotional weight or believability to make you buy into them. Hundreds of professional killers shoot at him and none of them even injure him, whereas he murders all of them with ease. This ends up very boring: you may as well be watching someone else play a video game.

For all the above griping, it's still a good old-fashioned action movie, and no worse than the previous one, but has little in it that would win over someone not already invested in the story from the first film.

5½/10.

The action scenes and fights are like a Hong Kong kung fu played at half speed. Not only are some of the fights slow but seem extremely and embarrassingly choreographed like a slow dance. Very unfortunate. I was really looking forward to watching this instalment. Not sure if the rumours about a fifth show are real. My advice if they are is to quit while they're ahead. The first two shows in the series were very well done. Great plotting and good dialogue. Show three began to fade a bit but was quite entertaining for various reasons. This fourth do not had the higher standards of the previous shows.

I can't believe there are so many people who rate this (and previous 3) movie as a "masterpiece" and gave them 10/10s.... It's beyond my understandings.

One movie was enough. More than enough. They decided to milk the cow for 3 more, and they've made a mistake.

Not that the first one was any good tho - an endless actions of gore and countless killings. How is that even watchable?

In this 4th movie the fight scenes were way too long and boring. 2 hr and 49 minutes, why so long???

These type of plotless movies should be not longer than 90-100 minutes - boom, boom, bang, bang, the end. Here we see no plot, shallow dialogues, too much killings, for what actually??

Does anyone understood why they're killing each others that fiercely? Because I couldn't get it...

Poor acting, poor music, poor camera work, poor directing and no plot. People rate it high only because of Keanu Reeves.

In reality they don't remember anything from the movie, just remember that the "good guy" kills them all.

Cheesy amateur dialog with tough guy attitude and stone faces acting like they are dropping Zen pearls of observation.

This is non-stop ballet of idiotic destruction for no purpose at all. A world of low IQ powerlustful idiots duke it out.

John Wick has no purpose other than to survive another day in his unexamined life of reflexive mayhem.

Tropes of loyalty and family loss are so lame, predictable, and ultimately without meaning as all sides are unworthy of admiration. A world of assassins who are ass-ass-ins.

An eye for an eye, but no one has a heart or brains. Watching pretty lights and fancy sets be destroyed may be some form of revenge-relief in today's Idiocracy, but all it does is stimulate the basest parts of your limbic system...which is what the Masters want in their quest to make you dumber and more complacent every generation.

...by how bad that movie is.

Was very surprised. The first three movies were very good. With a small decline in my eyes. But the fourth one is so inconsistent and not conscious where the first movies came from. It was painful watching.

The stuff I liked previously was the gritty style mixed with the brutal fast combat.

But the bigger is better formula combined with brainless scenes (Arque de Triumphe.... dafuq?!?) resulted into me shaking my head for the last 1,5h of the movie.

Don't get me started about the suit. Just seeing John hide behind his jacket all the time while fighting is so incredibly painful to watch.

And don't throw in 8254 baddies and when your solution is to coming up with the stupid idea of a bulletproof suit which also reduces any kinetic energy.

Sure. Action movies don't have to be realistic. But a solid foundation for believable action is important. Especially if you have those 3 movies before which delivered here.

Talking about believability.... Why have those shootouts at locations with soooooo many people and then there's literally no reaction?!? The club, arque de triumphe,... Full shootout with a looooot of gunmen and nobody is giving a damn?!?

Why? Just why?

Somebody wrote that script, had to present it and nobody raised there hand and pointed out how stupid that is?

The roles of the characters (the villains!) are incredibly stupid. Even by action standards. Don't know when it was the last time I heard so many bad accents and lines.

From visual perspective it is massively inconsistent. Sometimes it catches the vibe of the first movies. Nice scenes. Then it looks directly out of CGI hell with saturation put to 11 without any feeling for asthetics.

The scene in the building shot from above with the fire ammunition was looking more like a vampire top-down shooter game than a John Wick flick. Nice experiment though.

The movie is an utter mess.

Avoid!

I understand it is a franchise and there are some elements related to the universe / character and or backstory that are just beyond me (including the infinity bullets handgun), but the movie was a long meaningless killing video-clip it was illegally boring.

As a non JW fan I'd compare this to watching superman (not a fan either) anything else you would watch there would be a story a script an adventure of the character going through a journey.

Here there was non. I was just waiting for something interesting to happen.

I would have been better off watching a gameplay of FPS over a nicely made salty popcorn.

John wick 1 was pretty ok, John wick 2 was acctually very good, John wick 3 was pretty bad.. So now nr 4 is here...better than nr 3 but this is too much and as beliveable as a Doctor strange movie:-p. Every bad guy John wick kills , dies the exact same way : 3 bullets in the neck, then smash too the floor Judo style the. 2 moore bullets in the head, and he kills approx 400.000 bad gys this way😂. Donnie yens character Cain is also ' very belivable' blind and kill approx 120.00 bad gys and good gyus , also the exactly same way . So this gets very boring for almost 3 hours. I give it 5 stars just because Scott Adkins :Killa is funny an awesome( he kick John wick's ass, but John wick can not die so....🤓) Hiriyoka Sanada is also pretty good. 1 half is ok, second is over the top x 4.

The first 3 movies were fun. This one is so very bad and boring. I can not believe the rating is so high. None of the first 3 movies deserved 10 but this one was so bad. Wasn not fun, was not exciting, was not deep. It was nothing. I still have to write 350 characters but honestly there is nothing else to say. John wick 4 is a bad boring movie l. And I really hope this was the last one. There is obviously nothing else to do or show or shoot or make. Keanu is a super nice guy and I like him so I hope the movie will make enough cash. But it beyond my understanding how could some many people give it 10 points!

"John Wick: Chapter 4" is a film that offers what its trailer promises: action and more action, achieving a product whose production is outstanding, colorful cinematography and risky camera movements, as well as outstanding editing work and a soundtrack well done. Its big problem, the negative point, is the most important part: the script, which is repetitive, tired and unimaginative, exploiting the action theme without really having a coherent story. Everything ends up being absurd only with a good job in the fight choreography. An overrated film, practically bad and with an excessive duration for the null story it tells.

I'm struggling to see where all these high ratings are coming from! Poorly written script lacking continuity of the previous Wicks. This movie feels like the story is being made up as they move along under 3 hours of fighting. At two hours I was ready for this to end! Many of the fight scenes felt like previous scenes we've seen before that makes this movie extremely redundant and predictable. Maybe people don't want to see dialogue anymore. Instead a studio can give you hours of useless fight scenes over and over again! This one truly misses the mark. This wick on this candle is finished!!!!!

This film franchise has lost it's imagination, was anybody killed with anything other than a gun, knife, arrow, blade or car..? Maybe that one with the swat helmet, but this is just relentless murdering and the fight scenes look so rehearsed almost back to the 70s bruce lee films where only 1 can attack at a time, and the whole 20min arc du triumph scene was when i went and made a coffee.. the whole film could have been an hour shorter and nobody would have noticed.. the only bit i really did love was the radio station homage to the great great film The Warriors. Just waiting for the spin offs and Nobody 2.

I don't really get this movie. The main character barely speaks, and he is walking from place to place to fight, a shoot guns, there's nothing else to it. It's like and arcade shooting game, where you have to kill people in different scenarios, and sometimes you are almost beating that level but an enemy drops you back to stage 1, and then you have to kill more 200 enemies to move on to next level.

It's kinda difficult to understand why people like so much of this movie. I saw it on cinema with my gf, we were both bored after the first 15 minutes. So we're the other people in the room. Every one was yawning.

Ridiculous movie, and a huge waste of time.

How could you watch this movie and not laugh? If it was a comedy movie, I wouldn't have a problem with it. But as an action movie, it was really ridiculous.

In my opinion, if they want to make John Wick 5, he will have the power to fly, he can even shoot fire from his mouth or shoot lasers from his eyes.

Marvel can add the character of John Wick and become a member of the Avengers group, because he is stronger than all superheroes. Or if DC adds this character, I am sure it will be a serious threat to Superman.

With this type of movies, Hollywood is getting closer to Bollywood. I really hope John Wick 5 is not in the works, that's enough.

If you enjoy watching over-egged, relentless fight scenes with no real story then this is the film for you and your 2 brain cells. Easy to follow, limited dialogue and the bullets don't seem to kill anyone. Amazing how many times John Wick can fall down 220 plus steps and effortlessly get up and go again. Furthermore, the genius idea of a blind assassin might not be to everyone's taste but it's amazing what you can do these days with a walking stick. Bonus - you can get away with a sleep in the middle and still keep up. The actual storyline (if you can call it that) could have been wrapped up in 5 minutes, but I guess they had a film to make so needed to stretch it out - and boy, did they?!

John Wick Chapter 4 features another incredible physical performance from Keanu Reeves but not even he can defeat the twin villians of bloated runtime and extended universe nonsense.

The first act introduces a bunch of new characters to varying degrees of success. The most important is Donnie Yen as a blind former colleague of Wick forced out of retirement to hunt the protagonist down and the most fun is Shamier Anderson's "Tracker" who has a dog sidekick and is a prime candidate for a spin off. At the other end of the scale is The Marquis, the main villian of the piece. It's entertaining to see him pop up in ridiculously ostentatious locations throughout the film but his accent is ridiculous and any attempt at projecting menace is undermined by laughable dialogue. His response to a botched attempt to off Wick in a hotel is to say "the goal was not to kill John Wick, it was to kill the idea of John Wick", despite the fact the plan had definitely been to kill John Wick.

Wannabe cool dialogue falling flat on its face is a recurring theme throughout the stretched runtime. Lawrence Fishbourne spouts the same style of nonsense as he does in the previous films and while there is an attempt to flesh out the character of Winston (presumably with incoming series "The Continental" in mind) his attempts to impart sage wisdom just highlight the fact that, apart from Ian McShane's natural gruff cool, there isn't anything to him. Towards the end of the movie Wick embarks on a mad dash through Paris (a cool idea which probably should have been the whole film) but this too is suffers from a lame attempt at cool in the form of an obnoxious Warriors reference. What fits in a 70's New York gang flick jars in modern day Paris.

Chapter 4 does have some great action sequences, the stand out being a videogame inspired, overhead shoot out with Wick utilising a flamethrower shotgun and Reeves always shines when he is telling a story physically rather than through speech. The problem is there is just too much of everything. Too much rolling around shooting, too much using bullet proof jackets as a convenient way to extend fights and definitely too much high table, assassin tradition mumbo jumbo. Everyone likes to see John Wick do his thing, just not for nearly three hours.

5 traditions of phoney honour followed by 10 professional murderers.

I enjoyed the original movie, it had a story that worked within a graphic novel kind of way, the action was believable, there was character development, some decent performances, all boxes ticked for an above average action film. From then on however there has been a steady decline, culminating in this awful, barely watchable mess, featuring no story, unbelievable action, zero character development, and dialed in performances. The 'story' such as it is (really just a series of badly scripted contrivances to segway from one fight scene to the next) features yet another autocrat from the High Table pronouncing doom on Wick and all those that associate with him (again!) which heralds the expected ridiculous bloodbath taking place amongst civilians and police who barely notice punctuated by high sounding pronouncements from the protagonists that finally fizzles out after a mind numbing three hours - I'm so glad I didn't pay to see this! You could say the violence that follows is just what you expect from a John Wick movie except it's not; the fight choreography is slow and laboured like the stuntmen are waiting for Keanu to catch up, the combination of guns and swords just looks stupid and even the execution of the idea looks awkward, the trope of throw away bad guys literally lining up to fight the hero was laughable but forgivable in early Hong Kong action flicks but here is an utter cringe and repeated way too many times - the Paris steps section is a case in point, too long, too stupid, too unbelievable. Add to this the bizarre idea of armoured henchmen carried over from episode 3, which didn't work then either, plus ballistic office suits which give us the nonsensical vision of actors flipping up their suit jacket tails to protect themselves from gunfire like they are trying to avoid a rain shower! Laughable. The thinly drawn characters are perhaps the worst aspect of this debacle; Reeves as Wick clearly decided at 3 that he didn't need to bother and has regressed into the performance style that everyone criticised him for in his early career, minimal effort, dead eyed delivery, no emotional connection, just simply turn up, mouth some word salad, leap about and take the big fat cheque. But that's not all, the blind assassin trope from so many other films is done so badly here, nothing Donnie Yen does is remotely believable, again, bad guys line up to be knocked down, the choreography is sloppy, the actual character is so thinly drawn that a student in their first year of writing school could have knocked something out that was far more believable and there is zero chemistry between Yen and Reeves who are meant to have been best friends now tragically pitted against each other. Then we have Shamier Anderson as 'The Tracker' whose sole reason for existence seems to be to turn up at random moments to intervene conveniently and have plot exposition conversations with several of the protagonists, we know nothing about him, he has no arc and by the end know nothing more about him. By far the worst drawn and worst performed character is 'The Marquis', chief villain and opponent to Wick; this character makes no sense, he appears from nowhere with ultimate power and ultimate resources, inhabiting a faux C18TH world in plain site, literally blowing up hotels with no repercussions and yet has zero screen presence which is solely down to the insipid, boring and affected performance from Bill Skarsgard, why oh why would you cast a Swedish born, American based actor to play a French man badly? There are loads of good French actors out there who could perhaps have made this character work. Of the minor characters, Laurence Fishbourne turns up with nothing to do and Lance Reddick is treated abysmally but Hiroyuki Sanada does shine as the honourable samurai friend role and makes the most of a typically thinly drawn character. Top marks however go to Ian McShane who has taken a peripheral role and made it very much his own, acting everyone off the screen and being the only positive thing I could take away from this mess, thank you Ian. Ultimately me giving a film a bad review will make zero difference, people will have been ripped off at the box office, much money will have been made by the studios and rich people will be even richer, all I can hope is that someone takes notice and doesn't waste three hours of their life streaming it when they could watch something far better.

According to the plot, it simply does not exist, 1.5 hours of massacre and corpses. Didn't check it out. Actors are good but the movie is game. Fights and fights and fights....what's the point? This hasn't been filmed for a long time... what else can I say... the head of the table is simply ridiculous.... who chose the head of the clan.... well, it's not at all... Marquis Vincent? It doesn't play at all .... it would be better if they did a comedy .. The only phrase was something like "I am a Note")) Keanu is a pity, they made it some kind of Looser in the film ... constantly snatches .... constantly substituted .... and they don't take bullets ... and an endless magazine of cartridges .... and a sword fight against guns at the very beginning is generally trash .... spoiled the film with endless slaughter .... the first and second films were a top but the 4th is like a game where you need to wet everyone ... about nothing at all ...

.......except the plot is even more predictable. 80% of the same O gun fight scenes. How many times can you do the same thing, so boring and repetitive? I get it, all gun and no plot is its genre but at least hire some decent writers. Barely any new action or gun scenes. The producers are just milking this cash cow dry to the bone. This movie was 1hr toooooo long also. The only good thing was the music had good bass and fit the scenes and only if you watched in Dolby with the vibration seats.

.......except the plot is even more predictable. 80% of the same O gun fight scenes. How many times can you do the same thing, so boring and repetitive? I get it, all gun and no plot is its genre but at least hire some decent writers. Barely any new action or gun scenes. The producers are just milking this cash cow dry to the bone. This movie was 1hr toooooo long also. The only good thing was the music had good bass and fit the scenes and only if you watched in Dolby with the vibration seats.

Some reviews here, summarize the franchise very well, so I just wanted to copy paste it here:

"When Chad Stahelski directed the first movie he was not expecting all this success and when the production company ordered sequels, he did not really know how to develop this saga.

This got definitely out of hand and Wick basically became the parody of himself, with scenes that have forced comedic moments that do not quite deliver. In my perspective they really do not know what to invent anymore. "

"Who needs a 2hr and 40 min action movie? No one. Yes the action was good, but repeats so many times that it becomes so boring. How can hundreds of assassins not kill one man?"

"Seems after coming up with the bullet proof suit the writers etc thought it a good idea to make sure everyone has one. These giant men sent to kill Wick all wearing suits, raising the jacket to protect their heads was a sight I found so funny"

"He's the best hitman on the world, how do we kill him? I know, we'll send a blind man!! Pathetic. And he can dodge bullets and he knows where everyone is!"

The original John Wick was awesome and still the best out the three sequels it has spawned.

Two and three got progressively worse, taking John Wicks Martial arts into more gun play.

Hang on, we want to see more unarmed fighting than gun play, that's what made the first one so good.

So onto the fourth one, as my headline says, what happened?

They have taken away the human side if John Wick and his enemies and made them into bullet dodging, when they are close by.

All of them seem to be wearing bullet proof suits even John Wick is, come on, stop treating you audiences like idiots.

And last but not least, I know Keanu Reeves is getting older but the fight scenes were awful, a child could have done better.

Reeves looks so slow that it's embarrassing to watch him struggle through the fight scenes. I was almost embarrassed for him to be starring in this movie.

I know they are making a fifth and last one, I hope the revert back to the style of the original.

I struggled with this one, I give it a four star rating.

I guess if you love fight scenes, 3 hours of leaping, grunting and killing is even better than the customary two. For me, it got old and repetitive after hour #1 and I became distracted over and over. The only way to soldier on to the end was to pause and pick it up another day. I can't imagine sitting in a theater and watching the whole predictable story in a single session.

Of course the real distraction was seeing how Keanu had aged. He used to have a perfect radiance about him which kept him untouched through all the horrors he endured. In Chapter 4 it appears his Portrait of Dorian Grey has lost its magic and the effects of his punishing life are worn on his face. He needs to check in with Tom Cruise for make up recommendations.

After watching it twice, I thought it a far cry from the other 3 in the series. So many plot holes and while Keanu has been consistent throughout the story, the movie just did not make sense. I don't get the reference to "The Warriors" although kind of unique it came across as filler and unrelated. The stair scene was overplayed as was a lot of the action. This was the first time I saw Winston really not be Winston. The "King" was nowhere near "The King". Frankly I didn't like it. I thought it could have followed the pace of the previous films. This one just didn't make sense and was corny. Some kind of back story on the marquis would have been nice because based on the series, none of it made any sense.

I was never a big fan of this saga, even though the plot of these films is always basic, boring and predictable, the first one was kind of innovative in terms of the action and fighting sequences, but the rest were just more of the same.

Then all this buzz and hype came from the fourth so I was hoping they did some sort of revitalization of the saga and the first part of the movie indicated that but then its all ruined due to the same reasons as the previous installments.

There's no difference between this and super hero movies when it comes to the realism of the action scenes, the main character is indestructible, he can take punches, knifes, bullets (BUT he has a suit / vest that he uses to protect his face as you do when there's a bit of wind so I guess that makes sense), dozens of the best killers in the world, you see the point, he is a 1 man army with limitless stamina and upenetrable plot armor.

All of this becomes even more ridiculous when the fight scenes become slower as Keanu also ages, I mean I respect the man for doing his own stunts and he does look amazing for his age but come on.... and the fact that these boring unrealistic fighting scenes happen and the background regular people are just unfazed by it, is this suppose to be the Matrix as well? It just adds to the unrealistic environment.

I mentioned the movie started promising because there was a lot of interesting dialogue and character introduction, the stylization of different cultures and cities was also done well but then its lost on the predictable and ridiculous plot all over again... With that ending we still expect John Wick 5, seriously? It's so sickening these movies keep gaining millions, this worn out franchises, why do we continue to support this stuff....

Coming from 3 movies you expect a change of pace. Instead you find yourself in a movie which is so mashed up that you lose yourself at exactly what John is trying to achieve.

It seems like the director "buffed" his grunts just to prolong his fight scene. Now John needs to defeat enemies with bulletproof armour ( and jackets) forcing him to hit that all sweet "head shot".

This leaves the fight stale and meaningless, a constant back and force of gunfight leading to really nothing. While buffing the armour it seems the director forgot to program their aim, as grunt fire bullets but never seem to hit anything. The action sequences seems to go on forever but never really seems to get anywhere.

And then we have the stair scene.. I mean It seemed like John was performing at a comedy show at that moment. This exaggeration only to prove the point of " what do we do when we fall down 100 stairs?" We get back up and do it again.....

Disappointing, and you will see why when u watch it.

Love the Wick series, but this last chapter couldn't keep my attention. It seems that the filmmakers decided that a lot over the top action scenes are better than a good story.

Though the story has some memorable lines, it is drowned in over the top action scenes in which John just kills 100th people in his wake, gets shot at multiple times, falls from high above and walks away. Too much over the top for just being a top killer (not a superhero). Even Neo or Constantine couldn't pull this off.

When you skip the unreal action scenes, it's a good movie. But that shouldn't be the way to watch it.

A 90 minute movie padded out to 169 minutes. And the extra 79 minutes are just Wicks being hit by cars and hiding behind his bullet proof jacket! And the major grab from the 80's The Warriors, right down to the same choice of song was irritating and distracting. Fans who enjoyed the other 3 films will enjoy this, because it's exactly the same.

Keanu Reeves is just too old now. Just because the money men tell you a fourth film is a good idea, doesn't make it so. This is like watching someone else play a video game, it's fun initially but gets tiresome very quickly. I've given this a 3 because a 1 is probably too petty!

I hadn't watched a John Wick before. After watching ten minutes of this movie, I was relieved that I hadn't been missing anything. For those who just love seeing homicidal violence, John Wick is your ticket. Particularly for those loving guns and gun violence, this movie is a feast. The dead probably exceeded a hundred, or at least enough to start a decent-sized cemetery. It shouldn't be a surprise that gun violence is so prevalent in the US. As for other aspects of the film, stunts and special effects are impressive. These usually involve killing bad guys and chase scenes. The sets are also impressive in such cities as Paris, New York, Berlin, and Osaka. The plot has minor variations from the good guy - bad guy theme. Why they are good or bad is less obvious. Wick loves his dead wife and personal loyalty seems to matter with the good guys. A much stronger motivator for the bad guys is money and power at all cost. For that, John usually delivers a bullet in the head. I liked Ian McShane and Laurence Fisburne's acting in this movie, but Keanu Reeves seems a bit of a stiff. Caine and Mr. Nobody characters are interesting, mostly because their loyalties are unpredictable and seemingly capricious. All that said, I am not sure how the blind guy can see so well.

Too long by about 90 minutes, at the halfway point the director and writers decide to start the "narrative" (such as it is).

The gunplay becomes tiresome fairly early on in the film, it is so unrelenting that it becomes boring.

The film takes itself much less seriously than the first 3, actors in fat suits doing gymnastics, CGI dogs, bullets bouncing off lounge suits with a metallic clink, serious injuries healing in minutes. I would also be surprised if there was a single actual physical location used once, the whole thing looks green screened.

There is a general sloppiness on show, extras dancing in the nightclub scene, baddies obviously hesitating while the near 60yo hero gets to his mark in order to kill them etc.

The plot, such as it is, seems to have abandoned any effort at internal consistency to the rest of the franchise. Keanu phones in his "performance", he looks as bored with it as the rest of us. He's on a bum run at the moment; matrix 4, bill and Ted 3, wick 4, all stinkers. Ian McShane tries his best but he looks as tired as the dialogue.

There is not a single memorable scene in the film, not a single memorable line of dialogue. You may as well watch a kid play fortnight. Extremely disappointing. 5\10 and I'm being generous.

I had no hope for the second movie and it tried hard to be boring with its first soap-opera half. Yet, by the end, it got going and promised us an epic end to the trilogy. But instead of a trilogy, or an epic, the third movie was a just alright self-aggrandizing stupid pointless side story, that declared that this geriatric soap-opera will be going aimlessly as long as it's even a little bit profitable.

This entry is just several more hours of retcon world-building when there is no world. They at least pretended to hide and be discreet before, now they openly start shoot-outs and fights in public places and no one cares. Or sometimes they pretend they do. Like, the stupid club fight went for half an hour with them shooting openly near common patrons, before they've decided to flee. Pick one. Either in this world public murders are not an accepted thing, or they are. The characters are constantly talking about new stupid rules they make on the fly and pretend that this is proper writing and world-building. They pretend this is not a self-important ouroboros fanfic on the first film, which is actually written like axe-cop.

Keanu's acting of emotions is as bad as ever, starting with the first very awkward "yeah" he mutters. For the action scenes Keanu trained hard and practiced choreography for this ballet, but he didn't get 4 years younger since the last one. Or 10 years younger since the first one. 58 years of age. His hand(-ish)-to-hand(-ish) scenes are extremely slow and all the extras openly and noticeably help him to perform. Or just wait or flail around and fall by themselves without him even touching them. So much so, that when his scenes are intercut with the scenes of a pop-singer and her stunt doubles it's like switching from formula 1 to horse carriage races.

Skarsgard is not good here, and they blackface him as a frenchman.

Zhen Zidan's acting is pretty bad. It's like a school play and it takes you right out of this film. And, well it's a blind guy in a gunfight. They show him do tricks one or two times, but mostly this character is acting blindly. Every time his opponents remember that they have an upper hand, they instantly start to blabber to help him.

Then there's Marko Zaror and he is surprisingly good in his few scenes.

Using pistols and birdshot against super body armour wasn't enough. Now there're bows, katanas and tengu masks in the gun-fights. Because japan, amiright.

Besides the magic bulletproof suit Wick constantly falls from three storeys high and he is totally ok.

This repeat of the APB scene doesn't work at all. There already was a bounty on Wick, and they barely increased it. Nothing has changed between before and after. Also the deal for 40 was a personal agreement, how did it became applicable to everyone?

For the duel Wick chose the place and he chose poorly. He picked somewhere so far away he had to hike there and and be late. When he could pick something easily accessible.

The top down sequence where they shoot fireworks is the only good part of the movie, just for how weird it looks.

The choices of music are very cringe.

It's still not insufferable. There are still ways to make it worse. But this is not the end and they will find how make it worse. The ratio of good to bad makes it on average a tolerable waste of several hours of you nonrenewable life-span.

John Wick 4 was a total disappointment. There was no follow through from Chap 3.... John, after saving Winston's life in 3 and then is gunned down in a double cross by Winston, doesn't seek revenge against Winston or the vicious adjudicator.

In fact she isn't even in the film menaing there will be no showdown between them which would have been the normal course of events.

Chapter 4 seems like film independent of the other Wick films. The action scenes are so outrageous they turn Wick into a cartoon character.

Then there's the climax...Wick never makes good his pledge to destroy the High Table and ends up dead, We think.

A pointless waste of time. I couldn't help but feel utterly disappointed after catching John Wick 4. I mean, seriously, what a waste of time! I had high hopes for this one, but it turned out to be a snoozefest disguised as an action-packed extravaganza.

I get it, John Wick is this legendary assassin seeking revenge or whatever, but come on! The plot was so convoluted and confusing that I found myself daydreaming about my next walk in the park rather than trying to figure out who Wick was after this time.

And don't even get me started on the dialogue. I expected some badass one-liners and cool catchphrases, but it was like the writers had a contest to see who could come up with the most cliché and cringe-worthy lines. I half-expected John Wick to break out into a Shakespearean soliloquy at any moment.

As for the action scenes, sure, there were plenty of them, but they felt like a never-ending blur of bullets and punches. I couldn't even keep track of who was fighting who half the time. Where was the finesse? The choreography? It was just mindless violence without any substance. I'd rather rewatch a YouTube compilation of cats doing ninja moves.

And let's talk about the runtime - I found myself checking my watch every five minutes, wondering when this ordeal would finally be over. I could have spent that time doing something way more productive, like mastering the latest video game or catching up on sleep.

In conclusion, John Wick 4 was a total letdown. I wouldn't recommend it to anyone unless you're into headache-inducing plots, cringe-worthy dialogue, and action scenes that make you question the meaning of life. Save yourself the agony and find something more worthwhile to do with your time, like, I don't know, reorganizing your living room.

I think this is more of a very long, boring dance routine. One where the main dancer is Keanu Reeves and he is joined momentarily by either individuals or groups of dancers who only leave the stage when Reeves pretends to shoot them.

It's non-stop action in the way basketball is non-stop point scoring. It happens so much it is just not thrilling in the slightest. There's no build up or tension just this long dance routine. I watched it almost all the way through and then as it was supposedly building towards the end, I had to switch it off. I will never get this time back again.

Did I mention how plain silly it is that one of the main protagonists is blind but seemingly suffers no impairment through this as just 'knows' where everyone and everything is. He weirdly seems to remind me of that Jedi like character on Rogue One but at least that is justified as he uses the force to see. This guy just has a dance choreographer like all the other actors.

Absolutely ridiculous. Enjoyed the original film but the writers have completely lost their grip on reality on this one. Good stunts and the acting ok but come on.... OK, I was going to write a quick review but as you cannot on this platform here we go ... a blind man as an assassin? Really? Blind man hits extremely accurate shots throughout film that 20 20 eyesighted characters could not achieve on every occasion throughout the film. Really liked the stunts but the distinct lack of realism ruined the whole film. Complete nonsense from start to finish. I hope Keanu got paid enough to sell himself short. Please don't pay to see this.

It isn't.

The saving grace is from Donnie (IP man) whose action scenes really shone. I was sort of hoping Chapter 4 would be the last one because Chapter 3 was pretty bad too, Chapter 4 managed to be worse.

I can explain who the people who reviewed this and said "best action movie I've seen in a while", they are the same people who watched Transformers twice, once for the action and once for the "incredible story".

The action is slow-paced and mind-numbingly dumb, the story is non-existent and logically flawed. Several "twists and turns" make no sense whatsoever. I watched it last night and I've already repressed the memory of more than half the film.

I would barely have this running in the background. Do not watch. Pick up "Python for Beginners" instead and start learning to program. Or really anything else. It'll be more fun and more worth your time than this geriatric action film (also mind you I love John Wick and I love Keannu Reaves, but... this.... is just bad).

I saw so many 9s and 10s and didn't know what to think. Then I found the real reviews. Everything they say is totally accurate. It's neverending absurdity. Even when the dog gets hit by a car it just hood right up and is fine. That sums up this whole ridiculously long, never ending "fight" sequence. It really is just a non stop murder rampage. Any "story" in this movie, and it's really nonexistent, is ONLY there to somehow justify it all. It doesn't. I turned it off finally right as he made his way to the sunrise duel. It was just total nonsense at that point. Bullets don't hurt. Cars hitting you don't hurt. Everyone who HAS A CHANCE to kill him, chooses to wait and do it later. It's obnoxiously awful. WHATTA disappointment as I literally signed up to a streaming service JUST to watch this pile of I don't even know what.....

This movie tome seems like a long and boring and repetitive video-game (and is filmed like that, here and there). Also recycled (a vast portion has been taken from the previous part(s)). Although it has many normally good or even excellent actors, it also seems that, except for Mr. Reeves, nobody really broke a sweat here. And for Mr. Reeves it means literally: he really did hard physical labor, but that's OK, since (despite being a nice person and all) he is a truly bad actor (not only here). No facial expressions, no "inner dialogue", no gestures, no voice variations nothing. He just recites his scarce lines (of which most are "Yeah."), like a ragdoll. Shallow and empty. Vast budget shows, but that's all there is. This movie could be very well one hour shorter (and probably more watchable, with the denser content). It's like someone previously wrote in the comment: a slow (cheats: god mode, give health) protagonist with mostly non-competent enemies, all set to "can I play, daddy?" skill level. Sad. However, it will have its audience and earn some money (which is all that really counts).

I don't know what to say. I got bored of the gunfights after the first 5 minutes. Especially considering everyone had magical kevlar bulletproof suits that still allowed full range of movement. Meanwhile, they guys in full armour go down after a couple shots.

Having trouble shooting a guy? Let John just roll around on the floor for a bit and then headshot him. Luckily for John Wick, nobody thought to make a hoodie version of the kevlar suit.

And then how do they end the movie? With a gunfight! And one guy was blind!

Somebody approved this script. They should be ashamed of what they've allowed to happen to the character.

I went into it with such high hopes because at the time of this posting it had a 7.7 on imdb. Should have read recent reviews first I guess.

If you believe (like you should) that Wick 2 was a step down from Wick 1. And similarly, that Wick 3 was a step down from Wick 2. Then trust me when I tell you Wick 4 is a step even further down from Wick 3.

The first point I knew we were in trouble was during the Osaka Continental seige. The fight sequence was so long and drawn out I got bored. A lot of the bad guys are not fatally wounded at first and have a chance for a second attack WITH A MACHINE GUN ON THEIR ARM but still manage to get bested by one man and a pair of nun-chucks (sp?). Later in Paris there are multiple times Wick is surrounded by men with guns who could shoot him from the back or side yet somehow don't.

And I'm sorry, that wasn't an homage to The Warriors disc jockey - it was straight up copying.

I didn't finish it. It's almost 3 hours of headshots. I went out to walk the dog a little before 2 hrs and didn't pause it. When I came back in I started fast forwarding and then just gave up because I didn't care anymore.

I'm surprised to see Chapter 4 is the highest rated in the series so I must be in the minority who feels this was the weakest entry (so far, if rumors are to be believed about a 5th in development). Don't get me wrong, it ticks all the boxes to be a John Wick movie - there's slick fight sequences, gun-fu, and a healthy dose of suspension of disbelief to make it all work. My qualms aren't with any of that. No my issue is it felt a little bit too much like a Greatest Hits. I mean the core of John Wick (killing an improbable number of enemies while taking unrealistically little damage) is obviously there across the series, but the previous 3 each felt like they added an extra new element: the 2nd with everyone after him, the 3rd had Halle Berry and her assassin dogs + the Far East expansion pack...but the 4th? Well it just repeated those. The Osaka sequence feels like we saw a (more impressive) version of it in Parabellum. The Tracker and his assassin dog? Yep, saw all that in Parabellum (and again, done better mind you). Everyone after John the moment he pokes his nose out in the open? Yep, same as in Parabellum. The overhead shot of John fighting off 'bad guys' in a church en route to the duel was a cool sequence. That's it though, that few minute shot is probably all I'll remember of Chapter 4. As a result of all that, you really feel the runtime that approaches three (3!!) hours! Not once in any of the previous installments did I glance at the time, but oof Chapter 4 goes on for too long especially without doing anything new.

And that might yet have still been worth it if the ending didn't feel so...unfulfilling. So he finally has exacted all his revenge and he's finally free of the High Table again so he....dies? That's it? After all that he still died, he could've died in chapter one or two and nothing changes! And don't give me that 'oh he faked his death' because to what end? Why would he fake his death now that everyone has stopped coming after him? The whole point of the last two movies (5 hours of John Wick!) was that he wanted to be free from the contract on his head and the High Table so he can keep living to remember Helen and when he finally achieves that...dies. It makes the last two movies feel like a complete waste of time. And you can say the point of John Wick isn't really the plot, that's just an excuse to go from one fight sequence to the next, that would be fine if Chapter 4 had been as fresh with ideas as its predecessors.

If this was where it was gonna go, it should've got there and wrapped up in Parabellum. The duel was a 20min sequence that could have easily happened at the end of Parabellum after a second meeting with The Elder.

I've throughly enjoyed John Wick, and if nothing else Chapter 4 reinforced what a colossal missed opportunity Matrix 4 was as Keanu Reeves definitely still has it in him, but they'll have to get quite clever with the plot and bring some fresh ideas to any future installments if they're to change my mind that the John Wick series has run its course.

Cheap CGI, fighting scenes less believable than ever, too many fights and in general a too long movie.

My last John Wick movie. Even the blind man has not an ounce of realism. John falls from high buildings, gets hit by cars, by bullets, by punches, but he doesn't even get a scratch. Police is not existing in this universe and not even the blood has any realism.

It was such a pain to watch this. Really think Hollywood is producing less and less movies worth watching. The only good thing in the movie is the hope that this now really was the last of its kind. Somehow I doubt it. If $$$ are too tempting they might just spin the plot into him being still alive.

Totally overrated how was this an 8.2? There is alot action sure, the acting fluctuating between good and mediocre to laughable and woody. Some the action scenes are good but towards the end the action becomes monotonous and just plain ridiculous and repetitive almost slapstick comedy actions like Laurel and Hardy . There is just too much overacting in this movie... The steps fall scene near the end is just silly. There are some very flat scenes like the card game scenes. So the movie was overrated, didn't blow my mind and definitely I won't be watching this again ever.....I am glad I didn't pay to watch it.

The hype for this movie is on another level...

It seems John Wick gains fall-damage immunity at the end of Chapter 3.

The falls he survives are insane!

Bad guys die instantly from lesser falls in the movie, but John just gets up, shrugs it off, and starts shooting like nothing happened.

Every scene is meticulously made, but it's blurred behind the shower of bullets fired every milisecond.

In a big city scene, the fight is on throughout the city. John is killing bounty hunters, but there are no COPS to be found.

If you like shooting RPGs, you should watch it. Some scenes at the beginning have sloppy hand to hand fights, but they get better during the movie if you don't walk out before the end.

To start off with, very poor writing/story and the whole movie is stretched for no reason.

In anticipation for this film I had a movie marathon covering the first 3, and I gotta say its been tiring watching the same leg tackle over a million times done in all the films so far.. There are some absolutely ridiculous sequences of shootouts in public places just like the first 3 movies where people are completely oblivious to wtf is happening around them and that just ruins the immersion.

In all fairness, there are a couple of scenes that are definitely fresh. But that's about it.

The whole act with John wick in Tokyo was pure BS, and get this - If you edit out that whole situation in Tokyo the story doesn't change even one bit. Literally has ZERO weight for why it has to be in the film. The stunts in that sequence were definitely off and you can see Keanu struggle in those parts.

The movie does pick up after 01hr:40min mark and is really enjoyable as it gets to the end. Overall a decent film if you got nothing to watch.

John wick - a man of focus, commitment and sheer f##king will - the baba yaga - the one you send to kill the boogeyman - yadayada.. And his kryptonite are a bunch of made up rules. LMFAO.

I had to create an account just to review this train wreck. I dont understand the highly rated reviews audiences completely disregarding the nonsensical writing, nonstop loopholes in the plot that coincidentally appear when the story needs it, and complete lack of coherence. This is just a movie where you turn off all logical thought processes in your brain to watch mind numbing action sequences with no real weight, or depth. Theres nothing at stake. When you just have a movie with no story go through action no matter how good, you just end up with a 3 hr shell of plot armored, low stakes shlock. Peoples standards have always been low, (looking at you fast and furious coprophagists) but jesus, have some dignity.

... I am of the opinion that John Wick Chapter 4 is the longest and least likeable of the franchise. Well, it's definitely the longest at close to three hours and the least likeable for me for the following reasons:

The fight scenes are way too long and ludicrously staged. The CGI blood spray in the fight scenes is laughably amateurish as is some of the choreography.

John Wick is an assassin, a human being. He's not endowed with superpowers. He can't fly or leap tall buildings although you wouldn't know it after watching this 4th outing.

It's down to the director and the script. It must have been an easy pay day for the writer because there's hardly any dialogue. We get a few monosyllabic grunts from John Wick and then another idiotic poorly done fight scene.

I think JW5 should go back to basics. Sure, keep the fight scenes that made the franchise famous but at least cut them down a little.

"John Wick" had the potential to deliver a thrilling and captivating experience, but its decision to incorporate Russians and the Russian language left me profoundly disappointed. Given the recent aggression of Russia towards Ukraine, resulting in the tragic loss of innocent lives, the movie's choice to feature Russian characters and their language felt insensitive and misguided.

At a time when tensions are high and the world is grappling with the consequences of geopolitical conflicts, "John Wick" missed a crucial opportunity to address the issue responsibly. Rather than using the presence of Russian characters to shed light on the complexities of the situation, the film succumbed to tired stereotypes and one-dimensional portrayals. This approach inadvertently normalized a nation responsible for the suffering of countless civilians, undermining the gravity of the real-life events.

The inclusion of Russians in "John Wick" could have been an opportunity to explore themes of redemption, forgiveness, and the shared human experience. However, the film failed to rise to this challenge, and instead perpetuated a narrative that oversimplified and vilified an entire group of people. By neglecting to confront the harsh realities of the conflict and failing to offer a nuanced portrayal, the movie missed the mark and left me disheartened.

In a time when empathy and understanding are paramount, "John Wick" failed to rise above the expectations of responsible storytelling. Rather than using the power of cinema to bridge divides and foster empathy, it opted for a disappointing and divisive portrayal that only serves to perpetuate negative perceptions.
